  • Proposition 3.21. If F W M ! N is a smooth map, then its global differential dF W TM ! T N is a smooth map. (Lee 83)
  • By putting together the differentials of F at all points of M; we obtain a globally defined map between tangent bundles, called the global differential or global tangent map and denoted by dF W TM ! T N (Lee 83)
  • One important feature of the smooth structure we have defined on TM is that it makes the differential of a smooth map into a smooth map between tangent bundles. (Lee 83)
  • given a smooth curve W J ! M and t0 2 J , we define the velocity of at t 0 (Fig. 3.9), denoted 0 by 0 .t0 /, to be the vector 0 .t0 / D d  ˇ  2 T .t0 / M; ˇ d ˇˇ where d=dtj t0 is the standard coordinate basis vector in T t0 R. (Lee 84)
  • Corollary 3.25 (Computing the Differential Using a Velocity Vector). Suppose F W M ! N is a smooth map, p 2 M; and v 2 Tp M . Then dFp .v/ D .F ı /0 .0/ 0 for any smooth curve W J ! M such that 0 2 J , .0/ D p, and .0/ D v.  (Lee 85)
  • On the face of it, the preceding proposition tells us how to compute the velocity of a composite curve in terms of the differential. However, it is often much more useful to turn it around the other way, and use it as a streamlined way to compute differentials (Lee 85)
  • Proposition 3.24 (The Velocity of a Composite Curve). Let F W M ! N be a smooth map, and let W J ! M be a smooth curve. For any t0 2 J , the velocity at t D t0 of the composite curve F ı W J ! N is given by .F ı /0 .t0 / D dF 0 .t0 / : (Lee 85)
  • The next proposition shows that velocity vectors behave well under composition with smooth maps. (Lee 85)
  • Every v 2 Tp M is the velocity of some smooth curve in M . (Lee 85)
  • A smooth function element on M is an ordered pair .f; U /, where U is an open subset of M and f W U ! R is a smooth function. Given a point p 2 M; let us define an equivalence relation on the set of all smooth function elements whose domains contain p by setting .f; U /  .g; V / if f  g on some neighborhood of p. The equivalence class of a function element .f; U / is called the germ of f at p (Lee 86)
  • 1 A derivation of C 1 p .M / is a linear map v W Cp .M / ! R satisfying the following product rule analogous to (3.4): vŒfgp D f .p/vŒgp C g.p/vŒf p : It is common to define the tangent space to M at p as the vector space Dp M of derivations of Cp1 .M / (Lee 86)
  • Tangent Vectors as Derivations of the Space of Germs (Lee 86)
  • It is a real vector space and an associative algebra under the operations (Lee 86)
  • Tangent Vectors as Equivalence Classes of Curves (Lee 87)
  • Let Vp M denote the set of equivalence classes. (Lee 87)
  • the existence of a vector space structure on Vp M is not at all obvious. (Lee 87)
  • Yet another approach to defining the tangent space is based on the transformation rule (3.12) for the components of tangent vectors in coordinates. One defines at a point p 2 M to be a rule that assigns an ordered n-tuple v tangent vector 1 ; : : : ; v n 2 Rn to each smooth coordinate chart containing p, with the property that the n-tuples assigned to overlapping charts transform according to (3.12). (Lee 87)
  • In this approach, the velocity of a curve is defined by the usual Euclidean formula in coordinates, and the differential of F W M ! N is defined as the linear map determined by the Jacobian matrix of F in coordinates. (Lee 87)
  • Another common approach to tangent vectors is to define an intrinsic equivalence relation on the set of smooth curves with the same starting point, which captures the idea of “having the same velocity,” and to define a tangent vector as an equivalence class of curve (Lee 87)
  • The germ definition has a number of advantages. One of the most significant is that it makes the local nature of the tangent space clearer (Lee 87)
  • Because there do not exist analytic bump functions, the germ definition of tangent vectors is the only one available on real-analytic or complexanalytic manifolds (Lee 87)
  • The morphisms are required to satisfy the following axioms: (i) A SSOCIATIVITY: .f ı g/ ı h D f ı .g ı h/. (ii) E XISTENCE OF I DENTITIES: For each object X 2 Ob.C/, there exists an identity morphism IdX 2 HomC .X; X/, such that IdY ıf D f D f ı IdX for all f 2 HomC .X; Y /. (Lee 88)
  • The definition we have chosen, however abstract it may seem at first, has several advantages: it is relatively concrete (tangent 1 vectors are actual derivations of C 1 .M /, with no equivalence classes involved); it makes the vector space structure on Tp M obvious; and it leads to straightforward coordinate-independent definitions of differentials, velocities, (Lee 88)
  • A category in which both Ob.C/ and Hom.C/ are sets is called a small category, and one in which each class of morphisms HomC .X; Y / is a set is called locally small (Lee 89)
  • A pointed set is an ordered pair .X; p/, where X is a set and p is an element of X (Lee 89)
  • a map F W X ! X 0 is said to be a pointed map if F .p/ D p 0 ; (Lee 89)
  • Similarly, we can think of the assignments M 7! TM and F 7! dF (sending each smooth manifold to its tangent bundle and each smooth map to its global differential) as a covariant functor from Diff to itself, called the tangent functor. (Lee 90)
  • he tangent space functor is a covariant functor from the category Diff  of pointed smooth manifolds to the category VecR of real vector spaces. (Lee 90)
  • 3-7. (Lee 91)
  • 3-8. (Lee 91)
  • Three categories of such maps play special roles: smooth submersions (whose differentials are surjective everywhere), smooth immersions (whose differentials are injective everywhere), and smooth embeddings (injective smooth immersions that are also homeomorphisms onto their images). (Lee 92)
  • e smooth submersions play a role in smooth manifold theory closely analogous to the role played by quotient maps in topology. (Lee 92)
  • rank theorem, a corollary of the inverse function theorem (Lee 92)
  • Suppose M and N are smooth manifolds with or without boundary. Given a smooth map F W M ! N and a point p 2 M; we define the rank of F at p to be the rank of the linear map dFp W Tp M ! TF .p/ N ; it is the rank of the Jacobian matrix (Lee 92)
  • of F in any smooth chart, or the dimension of Im dFp  TF .p/ N (Lee 93)
  • . If F has the same rank r at every point, we say that it has constant rank, and write rank F D r. (Lee 93)
  • the rank of F at each point is bounded above by the minimum of fdim M; dim N g (Lee 93)
  • If the rank of dFp is equal to this upper bound, we say that F has full rank at p, and if F has full rank everywhere, we say F has full rank. (Lee 93)
  • A smooth map F W M ! N is called a smooth submersion if its differential is surjective at each point (or equivalently, if rank F D dim N ). It is called a smooth immersion if its differential is injective at each point (equivalently, rank F D dim M ). (Lee 93)
  • If dFp is surjective, then p has a neighborhood U such that F jU is a submersion. If dFp is injective, then p has a neighborhood U such that F jU is an immersion. (Lee 93)
  • the set of m  n matrices of full rank is an open subset of M.m  n; R/ (Lee 93)
  • so by continuity, the Jacobian (Lee 93)
  • smooth submersions and immersions behave locally like surjective and injective linear maps (Lee 93)
  • Then each of the projection maps  i W M1      Mk ! Mi is a smooth submersion (Lee 93)
  • W J ! M is a smooth curve (Lee 93)
  • is a smooth immersion if and only if 0 .t/ ¤ 0 for all t (Lee 93)
  • the projection  W TM ! M is a smooth submersion. (Lee 93)
  • Show that a composition of smooth submersions is a smooth submersion, and a composition of smooth immersions is a smooth immersion. (Lee 94)
  • a map F W M ! N is called a local diffeomorphism if every point p 2 M has a neighborhood U such that F .U / is open in N and F jU W U ! F .U / is a diffeomorphism. (Lee 94)
  • Theorem 4.5 (Inverse Function Theorem for Manifolds). Suppose M and N are smooth manifolds, and F W M ! N is a smooth map. If p 2 M is a point such that dFp is invertible, then there are connected neighborhoods U0 of p and V0 of F .p/ such that F jU0 W U0 ! V0 is a diffeomorphism. (Lee 94)

  • Theorem 4.14 (Global Rank Theorem). Let M and N be smooth manifolds, and suppose F W M ! N is a smooth map of constant rank. (a) If F is surjective, then it is a smooth submersion. (b) If F is injective, then it is a smooth immersion. (c) If F is bijective, then it is a diffeomorphism. (Lee 98)

  • a smooth embedding of M into N is a smooth immersion F W M ! N that is also a topological embedding, i.e., a homeomorphism onto its image F .M /  N in the subspace topology. (Lee 100)
  • not just a topological embedding that happens to be smooth. (Lee 100)
  • the inclusion map U ,! M is a smooth embedding. (Lee 100)

  • F is a smooth immersion if and only if every point in M has a neighborhood U  M such that F jU W U ! N is a smooth embedding. (Lee 102)
  • Theorem 4.25 (Local Embedding Theorem). (Lee 102)
  • Proof. One direction is immediate: if every point has a neighborhood on which F is a smooth embedding, then F has full rank everywhere, so it is a smooth immersion. (Lee 102)
  •  (Lee 103)
  • if X and Y are topological spaces, a continuous map F W X ! Y is called a topological immersion if every point of X has a neighborhood U such that F jU is a topological embedding (Lee 103)
  • If  W M ! N is any continuous map, a section of  is a continuous right inverse for , i.e., a continuous map  W N ! M such that  ı  D IdN : (Lee 103)
  • A local section of  is a continuous map  W U ! M defined on some open subset U  N and satisfying the analogous relation  ı  D IdU (Lee 103)
  • Theorem 4.26 (Local Section Theorem). Suppose M and N are smooth manifolds and  W M ! N is a smooth map. Then  is a smooth submersion if and only if every point of M is in the image of a smooth local section of . (Lee 103)
  •  (Lee 104)
  • if  W X ! Y is a continuous map, we say  is a topological submersion if every point of X is in the image of a (continuous) local section of . (Lee 104)
  •  W M ! N is a smooth submersion. Then  is an open map, and if it is surjective it is a quotient map. (Lee 104)
  • surjective smooth submersions play a role in smooth manifold theory analogous to the role of quotient maps in topology. (Lee 105)
  •  W M ! N is a surjective smooth submersion. (Lee 105)

  • covering map between topological spaces: this is a surjective continuous map  W E ! M between connected, locally path-connected spaces with the property that each point of M has a neighborhood U that is evenly covered, meaning that each component of  1 .U / is mapped homeomorphically onto U by  (Lee 106)
  • If E and M are connected smooth manifolds with or without boundary, a map  W E ! M is called a smooth covering map if  is smooth and surjective, and each point in M has a neighborhood U such that each 1 component of  1 .U / is mapped diffeomorphically onto U by  (Lee 106)
  • If E is simply connected, it is called the universal covering manifold of M . (Lee 106)
  • a smooth covering map is more than just a topological covering map that happens to be smooth: the definition requires in addition that the restriction of  to each component of the preimage of an evenly covered set be a diffeomorphism, not just a smooth homeomorphism. (Lee 106)
  • Proposition 4.33 (Properties of Smooth Coverings). (a) Every smooth covering map is a local diffeomorphism, a smooth submersion, an open map, and a quotient map. (b) An injective smooth covering map is a diffeomorphism. (c) A topological covering map is a smooth covering map if and only if it is a local diffeomorphism. (Lee 106)
  • Theorem 4.30 is a particularly useful tool for defining a smooth map out of the base of a covering space. (Lee 107)
  • smooth covering maps are surjective smooth submersions (Lee 107)
  •  W E ! M is a smooth covering map (Lee 107)
  • Given any evenly covered open subset U  M; any q 2 U , and any p in the fiber of  over q, there exists a unique smooth local section (Lee 107)
  •  W E ! M is a smooth covering map. Show that every local section of  is smooth. (Lee 107)
  • Proposition 4.40 (Covering Spaces of Smooth Manifolds). Suppose M is a connected smooth n-manifold, and  W E ! M is a topological covering map. Then E is a topological n-manifold, and has a unique smooth structure such that  is a smooth covering map. (Lee 107)
  • Proof. B (Lee 107)
  • on in  (Lee 109)
  • Corollary 4.43 (Existence of a Universal Covering Manifold). If M is a connected smooth manifold, there exists a simply connected smooth manifold M  , called the universal covering manifold of M , and a smooth covering map  W M  ! M. 0 The universal covering manifold is unique in the following sense: if M is any other  simply connected smooth manifold that admits a smooth covering map  0 W M 0 0 M; then there exists a diffeomorphism ˚ W M ! M such that  ı ˚ D . (Lee 109)
  • There are not many simple criteria for determining whether a given map is a smooth covering map, even if it is known to be a surjective local diffeomorphism. (Lee 109)
  • Proposition 4.46. Suppose E and M are nonempty connected smooth manifolds with or without boundary. If  W E ! M is a proper local diffeomorphism, then  is a smooth covering map. (Lee 109)
  • Proof. (Lee 109)
  •  is a local diffeomorphism, it is an open map, and because it is proper, it is a closed map (Lee 109)
  • Thus .E/ is both open and closed in M (Lee 109)
  • the most important type of smooth submanifolds, called embedded submanifolds. (Lee 113)
  • embedded submanifolds are most often presented as level sets of smooth maps (Lee 113)
  • analyzing the conditions under which level sets are smooth submanifolds (Lee 113)
  • that level sets of constantrank maps (in particular, smooth submersions) are always embedded submanifolds. (Lee 113)
  • called immersed submanifolds, which turn out to be the images of injective immersions (Lee 113)
  • An immersed submanifold looks locally like an embedded one, but globally it may have a topology that is different from the subspace topology. (Lee 113)
  • When is it possible to restrict the domain or codomain of a smooth map to a smooth submanifold and still retain smoothness? How can we identify the tangent space to a smooth submanifold as a subspace of the tangent space of its ambient manifold (Lee 113)
  • An embedded submanifold of M is a subset S  M that is a manifold (without boundary) in the subspace topology, endowed with a smooth structure with respect to which the inclusion map (Lee 113)
  • S ,! M is a smooth embedding. Embedded submanifolds are also called regular submanifold (Lee 114)
  • If S is an embedded submanifold of M; the difference dim M  dim S is called the codimension of S in M (Lee 114)
  • An embedded hypersurface is an embedded submanifold of codimension 1 (Lee 114)
  • The easiest embedded submanifolds to understand are those of codimension 0. (Lee 114)
  • we defined an open submanifold of M to be any open subset with the subspace topology and with the smooth charts obtained by restricting those of M (Lee 114)
  • Proposition 5.1 (Open Submanifolds). Suppose M is a smooth manifold. The embedded submanifolds of codimension 0 in M are exactly the open submanifolds. (Lee 114)
  • demonstrate several other ways to produce embedded submanifolds. (Lee 114)
  • F W N ! M is a smooth embedding. Let S D F .N / (Lee 114)
  • S is a topological manifold, and it has a unique smooth structure making it into an embedded submanifold of M with the property that F is a diffeomorphism onto its image. (Lee 114)
  • Then inclusion W U ,! M is a smooth embedding by definition, and therefore it is a local diffeomorphism (Lee 114)
  • open map by Proposition 4.6. (Lee 114)
  • Since every embedded submanifold is the image of a smooth embedding (namely its own inclusion map) (Lee 115)
  • are exactly the images of smooth embeddings. (Lee 115)
  • embedded submanifolds (Lee 115)
  • For each p 2 N , the subset M  fpg (called a slice (Lee 115)
  • is an embedded submanifold of M  N diffeomorphic to M . (Lee 115)
  • Proof. The set M  fpg is the image of the smooth embedding x 7! .x; p/.  (Lee 115)
  • .f / is an embedded m-dimensional submanifold of M  N (Lee 115)
  • M is a smooth m-manifold (Lee 115)
  • N is a smooth n-manifold (Lee 115)
  • An embedded submanifold S  M is said to be properly embedded if the inclusion S ,! M is a proper map. (Lee 115)
  • Then S is properly embedded if and only if it is a closed subset of M . (Lee 115)
  • Corollary 5.6. Every compact embedded submanifold is properly embedded. (Lee 116)
  • Proof. Compact subsets of Hausdorff spaces are closed. (Lee 116)
  • .f / is properly embedded in M  N . (Lee 116)
  • embedded submanifolds are modeled locally on the standard embedding of Rk into Rn (Lee 116)
  • a kdimensional slice of U (or simply a k-slice) is any subset of the form S D x 1 ; : : : ; x k ; x kC1 ; : : : ; x n 2 U W x kC1 D c kC1 ; : : : ; x n D c constants c kC1 ; : : : ; c n (Lee 116)

  • S is a kslice of U (Lee 116)
  • Given a subset S  M and a nonnegative integer k, we say that S satisfies the local k-slice condition if each point of S is contained in the domain of a smooth chart .U; ’/ for M such that S  U is a single k-slice in U (Lee 116)

  • S n is an embedded submanifold of RnC1 , because it is locally the graph of a smooth function (Lee 118)

  • the most effective technique is often to find an embedding of M into a larger smooth manifold M (Lee 119)
  • dary, and apply the preceding results in that context. Exevery smooth manifold with boundary can be embedded in such a way. (Lee 119)
  • ˚ W M ! N is any map and c is any point of N , we call the set ˚ 1 .c/ a level set of ˚ (Lee 119)
  • It is easy to find level sets of smooth functions that are not smooth submanifolds. (Lee 119)
  • For instance, consider the three smooth functions ; ˚; W R2 ! R defined by .x; y/ D x 2  y; ˚.x; y/ D x 2  y 2 ; .x; y/ D x 2  y 3 : (Lee 119)
  • Although the zero set of  (a parabola) is an embedded submanifold of R2 because it is the graph of the smooth function f .x/ D x 2 (Lee 119)
  • @M is a topological .n  1/-dimensional manifold (without boundary), and has a smooth structure such that it is a properly embedded submanifold of M . (Lee 119)
  • can be adapted to show that those level sets are in fact embedded submanifolds of Rn . But using the rank theorem, we can prove something much stronger. (Lee 120)
  • Theorem 5.12 (Constant-Rank Level Set Theorem). Let M and N be smooth manifolds, and let ˚ W M ! N be a smooth map with constant rank r. Each level set of ˚ is a properly embedded submanifold of codimension r in M . (Lee 120)
  • Corollary 5.13 (Submersion Level Set Theorem). If M and N are smooth manifolds and ˚ W M ! N is a smooth submersion, then each level set of ˚ is a properly embedded submanifold whose codimension is equal to the dimension of N . (Lee 120)
  • Proof. Every smooth submersion has constant rank equal to the dimension of its codomain.  (Lee 120)
  • if LW Rm ! Rr is a surjective linear map, then the kernel of L is a linear subspace of codimension r by the rank-nullity law (Lee 120)
  • the analogue of a surjective linear map is a smooth submersion, each of whose (local) component functions cuts down the dimension by one. (Lee 120)
  • you to show that neither the zero set of ˚ nor that of is an embedded submanifold. (Lee 120)
  • every closed subset of M can be expressed as the zero set of some smooth real-valued function. (Lee 120)
  • If ˚ W M ! N is a smooth map, a point p 2 M is said to be a regular point of ˚ if d˚p W Tp M ! T ˚.p/ N is surjective; it is a critical point of ˚ otherwise. (Lee 120)
  • that every point of M is critical if dim M < dim N , and every point is regular if and only if F is a submersion (Lee 120)
  • the set of regular points of ˚ is always an open subset of M (Lee 120)
  • A point c 2 N is said to be a regular value of ˚ if 1 every point of the level set ˚ 1 .c/ is a regular point, and a critical value otherwise. (Lee 120)
  • a level set ˚ 1 .c/ is (Lee 120)
  • Level sets may or may not be embedded submanifolds (Lee 121)
  • (points p such that d˚p is surjective). (Lee 121)
  • Corollary 5.14 (Regular Level Set Theorem). Every regular level set of a smooth map between smooth manifolds is a properly embedded submanifold whose codimension is equal to the dimension of the codomain. (Lee 121)
  • applies to empty level sets, which are both regular level sets and properly embedded submanifolds. (Lee 121)
  • set of the smooth set of embedded submanifold of RnC1 . The sphere is a r function f W RnC1 ! R given by f .x/ D jxj2 , since egular level P dfx .v/ D 2 i x i v i , which is surjective except at the origin. (Lee 121)
  • Not all embedded submanifolds can be expressed as level sets of smooth submersions. However, the next proposition shows that every embedded submanifold is at least locally of this form. (Lee 121)
  • S is an embedded k-submanifold of M if and only if every point of S has a neighborhood U in M such that U  S is a level set of a smooth submersion ˚ W U ! Rmk . (Lee 121)
  • called a regular level set if c is a regular value of ˚ (Lee 121)
  • a regular level set is a level set consisting entirely of regular points of ˚ (Lee 121)
  • By the submersion level set theorem, S  U is an embedded submanifold of U , so it satisfies the local slice condition; it follows that S is itself an embedded submanifold of M . (Lee 122)
  • S  M is an embedded submanifold, a smooth map ˚ W M ! N such that S is a regular level set of ˚ is called a defining map for S (Lee 122)
  • f .x/ D jxj2 is a defining function for the sphere (Lee 122)
  • Proposition 5.16 says that every embedded submanifold admits a local defining function in a neighborhood of each of its points. (Lee 122)
  • The surface of revolution determined by C is the subset SC  R3 given by S n p  o C D .x; y; z/ W x2 C y2; z 2 C : (Lee 122)
  • The set C is called its generating curve (Lee 122)
  • torus of revolution D (Lee 123)
  • is the surface of revolution obtained from the circle .r  2/2 C m the circle .r  2/2 C z 2 D 1 (Lee 123)
  • 1. It is a regular level set of the function ˚.x; y; z/ D x2 C y2  2 C z2, which is smooth on R3 minus the z-axis. (Lee 123)
  • embedded submanifolds are the most natural and common submanifolds and suffice for most purposes, it is sometimes important to consider a more general notion of submanifold. (Lee 123)
  • we will encounter subsets of smooth manifolds that are images of injective immersions, but not necessarily of embeddings (Lee 123)
  • sets that are images of injective immersions that are not embeddings: the figure-eight curve of Example 4.19 and the dense curve on the torus of Example 4.20 (Lee 123)
  • Neither of these sets is an embedded submanifold (Lee 123)
  • An immersed submanifold of M is a subset S  M endowed with a topology (not necessarily the subspace topology) (Lee 123)
  • a smooth structure with respect to which the inclusion map S ,! M is a smooth immersion (Lee 123)
  • As for embedded submanifolds, we define the codimension of S in M to be dim M  dim S . (Lee 123)
  • Every embedded submanifold is also an immersed submanifold. (Lee 123)
  • smooth submanifold without further qualification means an immersed one, which includes an embedded submanifold as a special case. (Lee 124)
  • smooth hypersurface without qualification means an immersed submanifold of codimension 1. (Lee 124)
  • Some authors define immersed submanifolds even more generally than we have, as images of smooth immersions with no injectivity requiremen (Lee 124)
  • Such a submanifold can have “self-crossings” at points where the immersion fails to be injective. We do not consider such sets as submanifolds (Lee 124)
  • immersed topological submanifold of M to be a subset S  M endowed with a topology such that it is a topological manifold and such that the inclusion map is a topological immersion. (Lee 124)
  • It is an embedded topological submanifold if the inclusion is a topological embedding. (Lee 124)
  • Immersed submanifolds often arise in the following way. (Lee 124)
  • F W N ! S is a diffeomorphism onto its image. (Lee 124)
  • F W N ! M is an injective smooth immersion. Let S D F .N (Lee 124)
  • now we also have to define the topology on S (Lee 124)
  • he composition is a smooth immersion. (Lee 125)
  • he figure-eight of Example 4.19 and the dense curve of Example 4.20 are images of injective smooth immersions (Lee 125)
  • They are not embedded submanifolds, because neither one has the subspace topology (Lee 125)
  • Given a smooth submanifold that is known only to be immersed, it is often useful to have simple criteria that guarantee that it is embedded. (Lee 125)
  • If any of the following holds, then S is embedded. (a) S has codimension 0 in M . (b) The inclusion map S  M is proper. (c) S is compact. (Lee 125)
  • Although many immersed submanifolds are not embedded, the next proposition shows that the local structure of an immersed submanifold is the same as that of an embedded one. (Lee 125)
  • for each p 2 S there exists a neighborhood U of p in S that is an embedded submanifold of M . (Lee 125)
  • An immersed submanifold is locally embedded (Lee 126)
  • It is important to be clear about what this proposition does and does not say: given an immersed submanifold S  M and a point p 2 S , it is possible to find a neighborhood U of p (in S ) such that U is embedded; but it may not be possible to find a neighborhood V of p in M such that V  S is embedded (see Fig. 5.8). (Lee 126)
  • A local parametrization of S is a continuous map X W U ! M whose domain is an open subset U  Rk , whose image is an open subset of S , and which, considered as a map into S , is a homeomorphism onto its image. It is called a smooth local parametrization if it is a diffeomorphism onto its image (with respect to S ’s smooth manifold structure). If the image of X is all of S , it is called a global parametrization. (Lee 126)
  • Suppose S  M is an immersed k-dimensional submanifold. A local param (Lee 126)
  • The map f W U ! Rn  Rk given by f .u/ D .u; f .u// is a smooth global parametrization of .f / (Lee 126)
  • alled a graph parametrization. (Lee 126)
  • The map ˇ W .; / ! R2 of Example 4.19 is a smooth global parametrization of S . (Lee 126)
  • Figure-Eight Curve (Lee 126)
  • U  Rn (Lee 126)
  • whether F is still smooth when its domain or codomain is restricted to a submanifold (Lee 127)
  • F jS W S ! N is smooth. (Lee 127)
  • F W M ! N is a smooth map, and S  M is an immersed or embedded submanifold (Lee 127)
  • The inclusion map W S ,! M is smooth by definition of an immersed submanifold (Lee 127)
  • When the codomain is restricted, however, the resulting map may not be smooth, (Lee 127)
  • Define a smooth map G W R ! R2 by G.t/ D .sin 2t; sin t/: (Lee 127)
  • sufficient conditions for a map to be smooth when its codomain is restricted to an immersed submanifold.It shows that the failure of continuity is the only thing that can go wrong. (Lee 127)
  • If F is continuous as a map from N to S , then F W N ! S is smooth (Lee 127)
  • In the special case in which the submanifold S is embedded, the continuity hypothesis is always satisfied. (Lee 128)
  • Then every smooth map F W N ! M whose image is contained in S is also smooth as a map from N to S . (Lee 128)
  • he conclusion of the preceding corollary fails for some immersed submanifolds such as the figure-eight curve (Lee 128)
  • are certain immersed but nonembedded submanifolds for which it holds (Lee 128)
  • M is a smooth manifold and S  M is an immersed submanifold, then S is said to be weakly embedded in (Lee 128)
  • M if every smooth map F W N ! M whose image lies in S is smooth as a map from N to S (Lee 129)
  • (Weakly embedded submanifolds are called initial submanifolds by some authors.) (Lee 129)
  • every embedded submanifold is weakly embedded. (Lee 129)
  • the figure-eight curve is not weakly embedded. However, the dense curve on the torus is weakly embedded (Lee 129)
  • e promised uniqueness theorem for the smooth manifold structure on an embedded submanifold. (Lee 129)
  • Theorem 5.31. Suppose M is a smooth manifold and S  M is an embedded submanifold. The subspace topology on S and the smooth structure described in Theorem 5.8 are the only topology and smooth structure with respect to which S is an embedded or immersed submanifold. (Lee 129)
  •  (Lee 129)
  • a subset S  M is an embedded submanifold if and only if it satisfies the local slice condition, and if so, its topology and smooth structure are uniquely determined (Lee 129)
  • Because the local slice condition is a local condition, if every point p 2 S has a neighborhood U  M such that U  S is an embedded k-submanifold of U , then S is an embedded k-submanifold of M . (Lee 129)
  • The preceding theorem is false in general if S is merely immersed (Lee 129)
  • For the given topology on S , there is only one smooth structure making S into an immersed submanifold. (Lee 130)
  • It is certainly possible for a given subset of M to have more than one topology making it into an immersed submanifold (Lee 130)
  • Theorem 5.33. If M is a smooth manifold and S  M is a weakly embedded submanifold, then S has only one topology and smooth structure with respect to which it is an immersed submanifold. (Lee 130)
  • two ways we might interpret the statement “f is smooth”: it might mean that f is smooth as a function on the smooth manifold S (i.e., each coordinate representation is smooth), or it might mean that it is smooth as a function on the subset S  M (i.e., it admits a smooth extension to a neighborhood of each point) (Lee 130)
  • f 2 C 1 .S/ always means that f is smooth in the former sense (as a function on the manifold S ). (Lee 130)
  • If S is embedded, then there exist a neighborhood U of S in M and a smooth function fz 2 C 1 .U / such that fzjS D f . (Lee 130)
  • If S is properly embedded, then the neighborhood U in part (a) can be taken to be all of M . (Lee 130)
  • We adopt the convention of identifying Tp S with its image under this map, thereby thinking of Tp S as a certain linear subspace of Tp M (Lee 131)
  • This identification makes sense regardless of whether S is embedded or immersed. (Lee 131)
  • A vector v 2 Tp M is in Tp S if and only if there is a smooth curve W J ! M whose image is contained in S , and which is also smooth as a map into S , such that 0 2 J , .0/ D p, and 0 .0/ D v (Lee 131)
  • As a subspace of Tp M; the tangent space Tp S is characterized by ˚ ˇ  S (Lee 131)
  •  (Lee 132)
  • If an embedded submanifold is characterized by a defining map, the defining map gives a concise characterization of its tangent space at each point, (Lee 132)
  • If ˚ W U ! N is any local defining map for S , then Tp S D Ker d˚p W Tp M ! T˚.p/ N for each p 2 S  U . (Lee 132)
  • S  M is an embedded submanifold. (Lee 132)
  • Corollary 5.39. Suppose S  M is a level set of a smooth submersion ˚ D .˚ 1 ; : : : ; ˚ k /W M ! Rk . A vector v 2 T p M is tangent to S if and only if v˚ 1 D    D v˚ k D 0. (Lee 132)
  • Formally, we make the following definition. If p 2 @M; a vector v 2 Tp M X Tp @M is said to be inwardpointing if for some " > 0 there exists a smooth curve W Œ0; “/ ! M such that .0/ D p and 0 .0/ D v, and it is outward-pointing if there exists such a curve whose domain is .”; 0. (Lee 133)
  • The inward-pointing vectors in Tp M are precisely those with positive x n -component, the outward-pointing ones are those with negative x n -component, and the ones tangent to @M are those with zero x n -component (Lee 133)
  • Thus, Tp M is the disjoint union of Tp @M; the set of inward-pointing vectors, and the set of outwardpointing vectors (Lee 133)
  • a boundary defining function for M is a smooth function f W M ! Œ0; 1/ such that f 1 .0/ D @M and dfp ¤ 0 for all p 2 @M . (Lee 133)
  • For example, f .x/ D 1  jxj2 is a boundary defining function for the x n. closed unit ball B (Lee 133)
  • Proposition 5.43. Every smooth manifold with boundary admits a boundary defining function. (Lee 133)
  •  (Lee 134)
  • whether S is an embedded submanifold. Because embedded submanifolds are exactly those subsets satisfying the local slice condition, this is simply a question about the subset S itself: either it is an embedded submanifold or it is not, and if so, the topology and smooth structure making it into an embedded submanifold are uniquely determined (Lee 134)
  • A more subtle question is whether S can be an immersed submanifold. (Lee 134)
  • whether there exist any topology and smooth structure on S making it into an immersed submanifold. (Lee 134)
  • it can be especially tricky to prove that S is not a smooth submanifold. (Lee 134)
  • A typical approach is to assume that it is, and then use one or more of the following phenomena to derive a contradiction:     At each p 2 S , the tangent space Tp S is a linear subspace of Tp M; with the same dimension at each point. Each point of S is in the image of a local parametrization of S . Each vector tangent to S is the velocity vector of some smooth curve in S . Each vector tangent to S annihilates every smooth function that is constant on S . (Lee 134)
  • Consider the subset S D f.x; y/ W y D jxjg  R2 . It is easy to check that S X f.0; 0/g (Lee 134)
  • Thus, there is no such smooth manifold structure. (Lee 135)
  • For some purposes (notably in the theory of integration), it is important also to consider submanifolds that have boundaries (Lee 135)
  • a regular domain in M is a properly embedded codimension-0 submanifold with boundary. (Lee 135)
  • Familiar examples are the x n  Rn , and the closed closed upper half space Hn  Rn , the closed unit ball B upper hemisphere in S n . (Lee 135)
  • The topological interior and boundary of D are equal to its manifold interior and boundary, respectively. (Lee 135)
  • Proposition 5.46. Suppose M is a smooth manifold without boundary and D  M is a regular domain. T (Lee 135)
  •  (Lee 136)
  • Proposition 5.47. Suppose M is a smooth manifold and f 2 C 1 .M /. 1 .1; b (a) For each regular value b of f , the sublevel set f 1 .1; b is a regular domain in M . 1 Œa; b (b) If a and b are two regular values of f with a < b, then f 1 Œa; b is a regular domain in M . (Lee 136)
  • 1 A set of the form f .1; b for b a regular value of f is called a regular sublevel set of f (Lee 136)
  • every regular sublevel set of a smooth real-valued function is a regular domain. (Lee 136)
  • If D  M is a regular domain and f 2 C 1 .M / is a smooth function such that D is a regular sublevel set of f , then f is called a defining function for D. (Lee 136)
  • Theorem 5.48. If M is a smooth manifold and D  M is a regular domain, then there exists a defining function for D. If D is compact, then f can be taken to be a smooth exhaustion function for M . (Lee 136)
  • Since we will have little reason to consider nonembedded submanifolds with boundary, (Lee 136)
  • we focus primarily on the embedded case. (Lee 136)
  • Every open subset of M is an embedded codimension-0 submanifold with (possibly empty) boundary. (Lee 136)
  • with the subspace topology F .N / is a topological manifold (Lee 136)
  • and it has a smooth structure making it into an embedded submani- (Lee 137)
  • An embedded submanifold with boundary in M is properly embedded if and only if it is closed. (Lee 137)
  • If S  M is an immersed submanifold with boundary, then for each p 2 S there exists a neighborhood U of p in S that is embedded in M . (Lee 137)
  • If S  M is an embedded k-dimensional submanifold with boundary, then S satisfies the local k-slice condition for submanifolds with boundary. (Lee 137)
  • Conversely, if S  M is a subset that satisfies the local k-slice condition for submanifolds with boundary, then with the subspace topology, (Lee 137)
  • making it into an embedded submanifold with boundary in M . (Lee 137)
  • S  M is an embedded submanifold with boundary. (Lee 137)
  • (a) R ESTRICTING THE D OMAIN : If F W M ! N is a smooth map, then F jS W S ! N is smooth. (b) R ESTRICTING THE C ODOMAIN : If @M D ¿ and F W N ! M is a smooth map whose image is contained in S , then F is smooth as a map from N to S . (Lee 137)
  • It is called the unit tangent bundle of M . (Lee 138)
  • the set of critical values of a smooth function has measure zero (Lee 140)
  • extend the notion of sets of measure zero to manifolds. (Lee 140)
  • they include such things as countable unions of submanifolds of positive codimension (Lee 140)
  • Whitney embedding theorem, which says that every smooth manifold can be smoothly embedded in some Euclidean space. (Lee 140)
  • the Whitney approximation theorem, which comes in two versions: every continuous real-valued or vector-valued function can be uniformly approximated by smooth ones, and every continuous map between smooth manifolds is homotopic to a smooth map. (Lee 140)
  • The third result is the transversality homotopy theorem, which says, among other things, that embedded submanifolds can always be deformed slightly so that they intersect “nicely” in a certain sense that we will make precise. (Lee 140)
  • smooth maps between manifolds of the same dimension take sets of measure zero to sets of measure zero (Lee 140)
  • Theorem (Lee 141)
  • Lemma 6.2. Suppose A  Rn is a compact subset whose intersection with fcg  Rn1 has .n  1/-dimensional measure zero for every c 2 R. Then A has n-dimensional measure zero. (Lee 141)
  • Proposition 6.3. Suppose A is an open or closed subset of Rn1 or Hn1 , and f W A ! R is a continuous function. Then the graph of f has measure zero in Rn . (Lee 142)
  • First assume A is compact. (Lee 142)
  • If A is noncompact, it is a countable union of compact subsets (Lee 142)
  • Every proper affine subspace of Rn has measure zero in Rn . (Lee 142)
  • Proposition 6.5. Suppose A  Rn has measure zero and F W A ! Rn is a smooth map. Then F .A/ has measure zero. (Lee 142)
  • having measure zero is diffeomorphism-invariant for subsets of Rn . (Lee 142)
  • Using the Lipschitz estimate for smooth functions (Lee 142)
  •  M has measure zero in M if for every smooth chart .U; ‘/ for M; the subset’.A  U /  Rn has n-dimensional measure zero (Lee 143)
  • we need only check this condition for a single collection of smooth charts whose domains cover A. (Lee 143)
  • Proposition 6.8. Suppose M is a smooth manifold with or without boundary and A  M has measure zero in M . Then M X A is dense in M . (Lee 143)
  • F W M ! N is a smooth map, and A  M is a subset of measure zero. Then F .A/ has measure zero in N . (Lee 143)
  • Theorem 6.10 (Sard’s Theorem). Suppose M and N are smooth manifolds with or without boundary and F W M ! N is a smooth map. Then the set of critical values of F has measure zero in N . (Lee 144)
  • Let C  U denote the set of critical points of F . We define a decreasing sequence of subsets C  C1  C2     as follows: C k D fx 2 C W for 1  i  k; all ith partial derivatives of F vanish at xg: (Lee 144)
  • By continuity, C and all of the Ck ’s are closed in U . We will prove in three steps that F .C / has measure zero. (Lee 144)
  • F .C X C1 / has measure zero (Lee 144)
  • S TEP 2: For each k, F .Ck X CkC1 / has measure zero. (Lee 145)
  • S TEP 3: For k > m=n  1, F .Ck / has measure zero. (Lee 146)
  • Corollary 6.11. Suppose M and N are smooth manifolds with or without boundary, and F W M ! N is a smooth map. If dim M < dim N , then F .M / has measure zero in N . (Lee 146)
  • Proof. In this case, each point of M is a critical point for F . (Lee 146)
  • Corollary 6.11 is false if F is merely assumed to be continuous. (Lee 146)
  • For example, there is a continuous map F W Œ0; 1 ! R2 whose image is the entire unit square Œ0; 1  Œ0; 1 (Lee 146)
  • Corollary 6.12. Suppose M is a smooth manifold with or without boundary, and S  M is an immersed submanifold with or without boundary. If dim S < dim M; then S has measure zero in M . (Lee 146)
  • Proof. Apply Corollary 6.11 to the inclusion map S ,! M . (Lee 146)
  • every smooth nmanifold with or without boundary is diffeomorphic to a properly embedded submanifold (with or without boundary) of R2nC1 . (Lee 146)
  • an injective immersion of an n-manifold into RN can be turned into an injective immersion into a lower-dimensional Euclidean space if N > 2n C 1. (Lee 147)
  •  v W RN ! RN 1 be the projection with kernel Rv (Lee 147)
  • If N > 2n C 1, then there is a dense set of vectors v 2 RN X RN 1 for which v jM is an injective immersion of M into RN 1 . (Lee 147)
  • In order for v jM to be injective, it is necessary and sufficient that p  q never be parallel to v when p and q are distinct points in M (Lee 147)
  • Similarly, in order for v jM to be a smooth immersion, it is necessary and sufficient that Tp M not contain any nonzero vectors in Ker d.v /p for any p 2 M (Lee 147)
  • Because v is linear, its differential is the same linear map (Lee 147)
  • this condition is equivalent to the requirement that Tp M not contain any nonzero vectors parallel to v. (Lee 147)
  • Let M  M  M denote the closed set M D f.p; p/ W p 2 M g (called the diagonal of M  M ), and let M0  TM denote the closed set M0 D f.p; 0/ 2 TM W p 2 M g (Lee 147)
  •  (Lee 147)
  • if an n-manifold admits an injective immersion into some Euclidean space, then it admits one into R2nC1 (Lee 147)
  • When M is compact, this map is actually an embedding by Proposition 4.22(c); but if M is not compact, we need to work a little harder to ensure that our injective immersions are also embeddings. (Lee 147)
  • Lemma 6.14. Let M be a smooth n-manifold with or without boundary. If M admits a smooth embedding into RN for some N , then it admits a proper smooth embedding into R2nC1 . (Lee 147)
  • define the tube with axis S and radius R to be the open subset TR .S/  RN consisting of points whose distance from S is less than R: T R .S/ D x 2 RN W jx  yj < R for some y 2 S : (Lee 147)
  • By applying the preceding lemma repeatedly, we can conclude that if a (Lee 147)
  • Theorem 6.15 (Whitney Embedding Theorem). Every smooth n-manifold with or without boundary admits a proper smooth embedding into R2nC1 . (Lee 149)
  • it suffices to show that M admits a smooth embedding into some Euclidean space. (Lee 149)
  • First suppose M is compact (Lee 149)
  • dFp is injective (Lee 150)
  • e (Lee 150)
  • Corollary 6.16. Every smooth n-dimensional manifold with or without boundary is diffeomorphic to a properly embedded submanifold (with or without boundary) of R 2nC1 . (Lee 150)
  • Corollary 6.17. Suppose M is a compact smooth n-manifold with or without boundary. If N  2n C 1, then every smooth map from M to RN can be uniformly approximated by embeddings. (Lee 150)
  • f we require only immersions rather than embeddings, we can lower the dimension by one. Theorem 6.18 (Whitney Immersion Theorem). Every smooth n-manifold with or without boundary admits a smooth immersion into R2n . (Lee 150)
  • Are there abstract smooth manifolds that are not diffeomorphic to embedded submanifolds of Euclidean space? Now we know that there are not. (Lee 150)
  • Theorem 6.19 (Strong Whitney Embedding Theorem). If n > 0, every smooth n-manifold admits a smooth embedding into R2n . (Lee 150)
  • Theorem 6.20 (Strong Whitney Immersion Theorem). If n > 1, every smooth n-manifold admits a smooth immersion into R2n1 . (Lee 151)
  • In fact, not even the strong Whitney theorems are sharp in all dimensions. In 1985, Ralph Cohen proved that every compact smooth n-manifold can be immersed in R2na.n/ , where a.n/ is the number of 1’s in the binary expression for n. Thus, for example, every 3-manifold can be immersed in R4 , while 4-manifolds require R7 . This result is the best possible in every dimension (Lee 151)
  • On the other hand, the best possible embedding dimension is known only for certain dimensions. For example, Whitney’s dimension 2n is optimal for manifolds of dimensions n D 1 and n D 2, but C.T.C. Wall showed in 1965 [Wal65] that every 3-manifold can be embedded in R5 (Lee 151)
  • Theorems 6.15 and 6.18 are sometimes called the easy or weak Whitney embedding and immersion theorems. (Lee 151)
  • any continuous function from a smooth manifold M into Rk can be uniformly approximated by a smooth function. (Lee 151)
  • If ı W M ! R is a positive continuous In fact, we will prove something stronger. If ı W M ! R is a positive continuous ˇ ˇ function, we say th ı.x/ for all x 2 M . (Lee 151)
  • F W M ! Rk is a continuous function. Given any positive continuous function ı W M ! R, there exists a smooth function Fz W M ! Rk that is ı-close to F . If F is smooth on a closed subset A  M; then Fz can be chosen to be equal to F on A (Lee 151)
  • extension lemma for smooth functions (Lemma 2.26), (Lee 151)
  • g (Lee 152)
  • Corollary 6.22. If M is a smooth manifold with or without boundary and ı W M ! R is a positive continuous function, there is a smooth function e W M ! R such that 0 < e.x/ < ı.x/ for all x 2 M . (Lee 152)
  • We would like to find a way to apply the Whitney approximation theorem to produce smooth approximations to continuous maps between smooth manifolds (Lee 152)
  • we can consider M as an embedded submanifold of some Euclidean space Rn , and approximate F by a smooth map into R (Lee 152)
  • However, in general, the image of this smooth map will not lie in M (Lee 152)
  • Suppose M  Rn is an embedded m-dimensional submanifold. For each x 2 M; we define the normal space to M at x to be the .n  m/-dimensional subspace N x M  Tx Rn consisting of all vectors that are orthogonal to Tx M with respect to the Euclidean dot product. The normal bundle of M , denoted by NM; is the subset of T Rn  Rn  Rn consisting of vectors that are normal to M : NM D .x; v/ 2 Rn  Rn W x 2 M; v 2 Nx M : (Lee 153)
  • Theorem 6.23. If M  Rn is an embedded m-dimensional submanifold, then NM is an embedded n-dimensional submanifold of T Rn  Rn  Rn . (Lee 153)
  • let .U; ’/ be a slice chart for M in Rn cen- (Lee 153)
  • This maps each normal space Nx M affinely onto the affine subspace through x and orthogonal to Tx M (Lee 154)
  • A tubular neighborhood of M is a neighborhood U of M in Rn that is the diffeomorphic image under E of an open subset V  NM of the form V D .x; v/ 2 NM W jvj < ı.x/ ; (6.4) for some positive continuous function ı W M ! R (Fig. 6.6). (Lee 154)
  • Theorem 6.24 (Tubular Neighborhood Theorem). Every embedded submanifold of Rn has a tubular neighborhood. (Lee 154)
  • A retraction of a topological space X onto a subspace M  X is a continuous map r W X ! M such that rjM is the identity map of M . (Lee 155)
  • Proposition 6.25. Let M  Rn be an embedded submanifold. If U is any tubular neighborhood of M; there exists a smooth map r W U ! M that is both a retraction and a smooth submersion. (Lee 155)
  • extend the Whitney approximation theorem to maps between manifolds. (Lee 156)
  • M is a smooth manifold (without boundary), and F W N ! M is a continuous map. Then F is homotopic to a smooth map (Lee 156)
  • M is a smooth manifold, A  N is a closed subset, and f W A ! M is a smooth map. Then f has a smooth extension to N if and only if it has a continuous extension to N . (Lee 156)
  • a homotopy H W N  I ! M is called a smooth homotopy if it is also a smooth map, in the sense that it extends to a smooth map on some neighborhood of N  I in N  R. Two maps are said to be smoothly homotopic if there is a smooth homotopy between them. (Lee 157)
  • Lemma 6.28. If N and M are smooth manifolds with or without boundary, smooth homotopy is an equivalence relation on the set of all smooth maps from N to M . (Lee 157)
  • If F and G are homotopic, then they are smoothly homotopic. (Lee 157)
  • When the target manifold has nonempty boundary, the analogues of Theorems 6.26 and 6.29 do not hold, (Lee 158)
  • if we do not insist on homotopy relative to a subset, the rest of the results can be extended to maps into manifolds with boundary. (Lee 158)
  • submanifolds can be perturbed so that they intersect “nicely. (Lee 158)
  • it is easy to come up with examples of smooth submanifolds whose intersection is not a submanifold. (Lee 158)
  • Two embedded submanifolds S; S 0  M are said to intersect transversely if for each p 2 S  S 0 , the tangent spaces T p S and Tp S 0 together span T p M (where we consider Tp S and Tp S 0 as subspaces of T p M ). (Lee 158)
  • If F W N ! M is a smooth map and S  M is an embedded submanifold, we say that F is transverse to S if for every x 2 F 1 .S/, the spaces T F .x/ S and dFx .Tx N / together span TF .x/ M (Lee 158)
  • if F is a smooth submersion, then it is automatically transverse to every embedded submanifold of M (Lee 158)
  • Two embedded submanifolds intersect transversely if and only if the inclusion of either one is transverse to the other. (Lee 158)
  • The next result, a generalization of the regular level set theorem, shows why transversality is desirable. (Lee 158)
  • S  M is an embedded submanifold. (Lee 159)
  • If F W N ! M is a smooth map that is transverse to S , then F 1 .S/ is an embedded submanifold of N whose codimension is equal to the codimension of S in M . (Lee 159)
  • If S 0  M is an embedded submanifold that intersects S transversely, then S  S 0 is an embedded submanifold of M whose codimension is equal to the sum of the codimensions of S and S 0 . (Lee 159)
  • For example, in R3 , this theorem shows that a smooth curve and a smooth surface intersecting transversely have only isolated points in their intersection, while two smooth surfaces intersect transversely in a smooth curve (Lee 159)
  • Two smooth curves in R 3 intersect transversely if and only if their intersection is empty, because at any intersection point, the two one-dimensional tangent spaces to the curves would have to span the tangent space to R3 (Lee 159)
  • Corollary 6.31. Suppose N and M are smooth manifolds, S  M is an embedded submanifold of codimension k, and F W N ! M is a submersion. Then F 1 .S/ is an embedded codimension-k submanifold of N . (Lee 159)
  • Transversality also provides a convenient criterion for recognizing a submanifold as a graph. The next theorem is a global version of the implicit function theorem. Theorem 6.32 (Global Characterization of Graphs). Suppose M and N are smooth manifolds and S  M  N is an immersed submanifold. Let M and N denote the projections from M  N onto M and N , respectively. The following are equivalent. (a) S is the graph of a smooth map f W M ! N . (Lee 159)
  • ˇ (b) M ˇS is a diffeomorphism from S onto M . (c) For each p 2 M; the submanifolds S and fpg  N intersect transversely in exactly one point. If these conditions nditions  ˇ  ho (Lee 160)
  • Corollary 6.33 (Local Characterization of Graphs). Suppose M and N are smooth manifolds, S  M  N is an immersed submanifold, and .p; q/ 2 S . If S intersects the submanifold fpg  N transversely at .p; q/, then there exist a neighborhood U of p in M and a neighborhood V of .p; q/ in S such that V is the graph of a smooth map f W U ! N . (Lee 160)
  • The hypothesis guarantees that d.M /.p;q/ W T.p;q/ S ! Tp M is an isomorˇ phism, so M ˇS restricts to to a neighborhood U of p. (Lee 160)
  • The collection fFs W s 2 Sg is called a smooth family of maps if the map F W M  S ! N defined by F .x; s/ D Fs .x/ is smooth (Lee 160)
  • think of such a family as a higher-dimensional analogue of a homotopy. (Lee 160)
  • The next proposition shows how such families are related to ordinary homotopies. (Lee 160)
  • Proposition 6.34. If fFs W s 2 Sg is a smooth family of maps from N to M and S is connected, then for any s1 ; s2 2 S , the maps Fs1 ; Fs2 W N ! M are homotopic. (Lee 160)
  • which gives a simple sufficient condition for a family of smooth maps to contain at least one map that is transverse to a given submanifold (Lee 160)
  • If S is a smooth manifold and B  S is a subset whose complement has measure zero in S , we say that B contains almost every element of S . (Lee 160)
  • If the map F W N  S ! M is transverse to X , then for almost every s 2 S , the map Fs W N ! M is transverse to X . (Lee 160)
  • Theorem 6.36 (Transversality Homotopy Theorem). Suppose M and N are smooth manifolds and X  M is an embedded submanifold. Every smooth map f W N ! M is homotopic to a smooth map g W N ! M that is transverse to X . (Lee 161)
  • In order to make use of the parametric transversality theorem, we need to construct a smooth family of maps satisfying the hypothesis. The proof of the next theorem shows that it is always possible to do so. (Lee 161)
  • Lie groups, which are smooth manifolds that are also groups in which multiplication and inversion are smooth maps (Lee 165)
  • c (Lee 166)
  • A Lie group is a smooth manifold G (without boundary) that is also a group in the algebraic sense, with the property that the multiplication map mW G  G ! G and inversion map i W G ! G, given by m.g; h/ D gh; i.g/ D g 1 ; are both smooth. A Lie group is, in particular, a topological group (a topological space with a group structure such that the multiplication and inversion maps are continuous). (Lee 166)
  • It is traditional to denote the identity element of an arbitrary Lie group by the symbol e (for German Einselement, “unit element”), and we follow this convention, (Lee 166)
  • Proposition 7.1. If G is a smooth manifold with a group structure such that the map G  G ! G given by .g; h/ 7! gh1 is smooth, then G is a Lie group. (Lee 166)
  • If G is a Lie group, any element g 2 G defines maps Lg ; Rg W G ! G, called left translation and right translation, respectively, by L g .h/ D gh; Rg .h/ D hg: (Lee 166)
  • Because Lg can be expressed as the composition of smooth maps  g m G ! G  G ! G; where g .h/ D .g; h/ and m is multiplication, it follows that Lg is smooth (Lee 166)
  • It is actually a diffeomorphism of G, because Lg 1 is a smooth inverse for it (Lee 166)
  • we can systematically map any point to any other by such a global diffeomorphism. (Lee 166)
  • and it is an open submanifold of the vector space M.n; R/ (Lee 166)
  • Multiplication is smooth because the matrix entries of a product matrix AB are polynomials in the entries of A and B. Inversion is smooth by Cramer’s rule. (Lee 166)
  • Let GLC .n; R/ denote the subset of GL.n; R/ consisting of matrices with w positive determinant. (Lee 167)
  • it is a subgroup of GL.n; R/; and because it is the preimage of .0; 1/ under the continuous determinant function, (Lee 167)
  • With appropriate angle functions as local coordinates on open subsets of S1 (see Problem 1-8), multiplication and inversion have the smooth coordinate expressions .1 ; 2 / 7! 1 C 2 and  7!  (Lee 167)
  • f G and H are Lie groups, a Lie group homomorphism from G to H is a smooth map F W G ! H that is also a group homomorphism. It is called a Lie group isomorphism if it is also a diffeomorphism, which implies that it has an inverse that is also a Lie group homomorphism. In this case we say that G and H are isomorphic Lie groups. (Lee 168)
  • S 1 ,! C  is a Lie group homomorphism. (Lee 168)
  • the map expW R ! R given by exp.t/ D e t is smooth, and is a Lie group homomorphism because e .sCt/ D e s e t (Lee 168)
  • expW C ! C  given by exp.z/ D e z is a Lie group homomorphism. (Lee 168)
  • It is surjective but not injective, (Lee 168)
  • The map “W R ! S1 defined by”.t/ D e 2 i t is a Lie group homomorphism whose kernel is the set Z of integers (Lee 168)
  • (Lee 168)
  • conjugation by g is the map Cg W G ! G given by Cg .h/ D ghg 1 (Lee 168)
  • A subgroup H  G is said to be normal if Cg .H / D H for every g 2 G. (Lee 168)
  • , (Lee 168)
  • Theorem 7.5. Every Lie group homomorphism has constant rank. (Lee 168)
  • Corollary 7.6. A Lie group homomorphism is a Lie group isomorphism if and only if it is bijective. (Lee 169)
  • Proof. The global rank theorem shows that a bijective Lie group homomorphism is a diffeomorphism. (Lee 169)
  • Theorem 7.7 (Existence of a Universal Covering Group). Let G be a connected z called the universal coverLie group. There exists a simply connected Lie group G, z ! G that is also a Lie ing group of G , that admits a smooth covering map  W G group homomorphism. (Lee 169)
  • The following proposition shows that embedded subgroups are automatically Lie subgroups. (Lee 171)
  • Proposition 7.11. Let G be a Lie group, and suppose H  G is a subgroup that is also an embedded submanifold. Then H is a Lie subgroup. (Lee 171)
  • The simplest examples of embedded Lie subgroups are the open subgroups. The following lemma shows that the possibilities for open subgroups are limited. Lemma 7.12. Suppose G is a Lie group and H  G is an open subgroup. Then H is an embedded Lie subgroup. In addition, H is closed, so it is a union of connected components of G. (Lee 171)
  • If G is a group and S  G, the subgroup generated by S is the smallest subgroup containing S (i.e., the intersection of all subgroups containing S ). (Lee 171)
  • he subgroup generated by S is equal to the set of all elements of G that can be expressed as finite products of elements of S and their inverses. (Lee 171)
  • Proposition 7.14. Suppose G is a Lie group, and W  G is any neighborhood of the identity. (a) W generates an open subgroup of G. (b) If W is connected, it generates a connected open subgroup of G. (c) If G is connected, then W generates G. (Lee 171)
  • If G is a Lie group, the connected component of G containing the identity is called the identity component of G . (Lee 172)
  • Proposition 7.15. Let G be a Lie group and let G0 be its identity component. Then G 0 is a normal subgroup of G, and is the only connected open subgroup. Every connected component of G is diffeomorphic to G0 . (Lee 172)
  • Proposition 7.16. Let F W G ! H be a Lie group homomorphism. The kernel of F is a properly embedded Lie subgroup of G, whose codimension is equal to the rank of F . (Lee 172)
  • Proposition 7.17. If F W G ! H is an injective Lie group homomorphism, the image of F has a unique smooth manifold structure such that F .G/ is a Lie subgroup of H and F W G ! F .G/ is a Lie group isomorphism. (Lee 172)
  • Complementary to the preceding result about kernels is the following result about images. (Lee 172)
  • The following proposition shows how to produce many more examples of embedded Lie subgroups. (Lee 172)
  • Embedded Lie Subgroups). (Lee 173)
  • GLC .n; R/  GL.n; R/ (Lee 173)
  • S1 is an embedded Lie subgroup of C  (Lee 173)
  • SL.n; R/ (Lee 173)
  • SL.n; R/ is the kernel of the Lie group homomorphism detW GL.n; R/ ! R , it is a properly embedded Lie subgroup (Lee 173)
  • Because the determinant function is surjective, it is a smooth submersion by the global rank theorem, so SL.n; R/ has dimension n2  1. (Lee 173)
  • Therefore, SL.n; C/ D Ker.det/ is a properly embedded Lie subgroup whose codimension is equal to dim C  D 2 and whose dimension is therefore 2n2  2. (Lee 173)
  • ere is an example of a Lie subgroup that is not embedded. (Lee 173)
  • In Chapter 20, we will see that the subgroup S  T 3 described in the preceding exercise is typical of nonembedded Lie subgroups: they are all dense subgroups of properly embedded Lie subgroups (Lee 174)
  • In general, smooth submanifolds can be closed without being embedded (Lee 174)
  • or embedded without being closed (as is the open unit ball in Rn ) (Lee 174)
  • (as is, for example, the figure-eight curve of Example 5.19) (Lee 174)
  • However, as the next theorem shows, Lie subgroups have the remarkable property that closedness and embeddedness are not independent. This means that every embedded Lie subgroup is properly embedded. (Lee 174)
  • Theorem 7.21. Suppose G is a Lie group and H  G is a Lie subgroup. Then H is closed in G if and only if it is embedded. (Lee 174)
  • In Chapter 20, we will be able to prove a significantly strengthened form of this theorem, called the closed subgroup theorem, which asserts that every subgroup of a Lie group that is topologically a closed subset (but not assumed to be a submanifold) is automatically a properly embedded Lie subgroup (Lee 176)
  • If G is a group and M is a set, a left action of G on M is a map G  M ! M; often written as .g; p/ 7! g  p, that satisfies 1  .g2  p/ D .g1 g2 /  p epDp for all g1 ; g2 2 G and p 2 M I for all p 2 M: (Lee 176)
  • If M is a topological space and G is a topological group, an action of G on M is said to be a continuous action if the defining map G  M ! M or M  G ! M is continuous. In this case, M is said to be a (left or right) G -space. If in addition M is a smooth manifold with or without boundary, G is a Lie group, and the defining map is smooth, then the action is said to be a smooth action (Lee 176)
  • For a smooth action, each map g W M ! M is a diffeomorphism, because g 1 is a smooth inverse for it. (Lee 177)
  • A right action can always be converted to a left action by the trick of defining g  p to be p  g 1 , and a left action can similarly be converted to a right action (Lee 177)
  • For each p 2 M; the orbit of p, denoted by G  p, is the set of all images of p under the action by elements of G: G  p D fg  p W g 2 Gg: (Lee 177)
  • For each p 2 M; the isotropy group or stabilizer of p, denoted by Gp , is the set of elements of G that fix p: Gp D fg 2 G W g  p D pg: (Lee 177)
  • The action is said to be transitive if for every pair of points p; q 2 M; there exists g 2 G such that g  p D q, or equivalently if the only orbit is all of M . (Lee 177)
  • The action is said to be free if the only element of G that fixes any element of M is the identity: g  p D p for some p 2 M implies g D e, or equivalently if every isotropy group is trivial. (Lee 177)
  • Lie Group Actions). (Lee 178)
  • the trivial action of G on M is defined by g  p D p for all g 2 G and p 2 (Lee 178)
  • natural action of GL.n; R/ on Rn is the left action given by matrix multiplication: .A; x/ 7! Ax (Lee 178)
  • Every Lie group G acts smoothly on itself by left translation (Lee 178)
  • Every Lie group acts smoothly on itself by conjugation: g  h D ghg (Lee 178)
  • An action of a discrete group  on a manifold M is smooth if and only if for each g 2  , the map p 7! g  p is a smooth map from M to itself (Lee 178)
  • Z n acts smoothly and freely on Rn by left translation: 1      m ; : : : ; mn  x 1 ; : : : ; x n D m1 C x 1 ; : : : ; mn C x n : (Lee 178)
  • Suppose E and M are topological spaces, and  W E ! M is a (topological) covering map. An automorphism of  (also called a deck transformation or covering transformation) is a homeomorphism ’ W E ! E such that  ı ’ D  (Lee 178)
  • The set Aut .E/ of all automorphisms of , called the automorphism group of , (Lee 178)
  • t can be shown that Aut .E/ (Lee 178)
  • covering map, which cov  of  if and only if  is a normal acts transitively on each fiber means that  1 .E; q/ is a normal subgroup of 1 M; .q/ for every q 2 E (Lee 178)
  • With the discrete topology, the automorphism group Aut .E/ is a zero-dimensional Lie group acting smoothly and freely on E. (Lee 178)
  •  W E ! M is a smooth covering map. W (Lee 178)
  • A map F W M ! N is said to be equivariant with respect to the given G-actions if for each g 2 G, F .g  p/ D g  F .p/ (for left actions); F .p  g/ D F .p/  g (for right actions): (Lee 179)
  • Equivalently, if  and ’ are the given actions on M and N , respectively, F is equivariant if the following diagram commutes for each g 2 G: (Lee 179)
  • This condition is also expressed by saying that F intertwines  and ’. (Lee 179)
  • The smooth map “n W Rn !     r t 2 R, x 1 ; : : : ; x n 2 Rn , and z 1 ; : : : ; z n 2 T n 1 1 T n given by”n x 1 ; : : : ; x n D e 2 ix ; : : : ; e 2 ix is equivariant with respect to these actions. (Lee 180)
  • useful tool for proving that certain maps have constant rank. (Lee 180)
  • Suppose F W M ! N is a smooth map that is equivariant with respect to a transitive smooth G-action on M and any smooth G-action on N . Then F has constant rank. Thus, if F is surjective, it is a smooth submersion; if it is injective, it is a smooth immersion; and if it is bijective, it is a diffeomorphism. (Lee 180)
  • an important application of the equivariant rank theorem (Lee 180)
  • For each p 2 M; define a map (Lee 180)
  •  .p/ W G ! M by D g  p: (7.9) This is often called the preimage  .p/ 1 .p/ is the isotropy group Gp . (Lee 181)
  • For each p 2 M; the or.p/ bit map  .p/ W G ! M is smooth and has constant rank, so the isotropy group p  .p/ W  .p/ 1 Gp D  .p/ is a properly embedded Lie subgroup of G. If Gp D feg, then  .p/ is an injective smooth immersion, so the orbit G  p is an immersed submanifold of M . (Lee 181)
  • It is a fact that every orbit is an immersed submanifold of M; not just the ones corresponding to trivial isotropy groups (Lee 181)
  • Next we use the equivariant rank theorem to identify some important Lie subgroups of the general linear groups. (Lee 181)
  • orthogonal if as a linear map AW Rn ! Rn it preserves the Euclidean dot product: .Ax/  .Ay/ D x  y for all x; y 2 R n : (Lee 181)
  • The set O.n/ of all orthogonal n  n matrices is a subgroup of GL.n; R/, called the orthogonal group of degree n (Lee 181)
  • R n to an orthonormal basis, which is equivalent to the columns of A being orthonormal. (Lee 181)
  • also equivalent to the requirement that AT A D In . (Lee 182)
  • Define a smooth map ˚ W GL.n; R/ ! M.n; R/ by ˚.A/ D AT A. Then O.n/ is equal to the level set ˚ 1 .In /. (Lee 182)
  • To show that ˚ has constant rank and therefore that O.n/ is an embedded Lie subgroup, we show that ˚ is equivariant with respect to suitable right actions of GL.n; R/ (Lee 182)
  • (Lee 182)
  • To determine the dimension of O.n/, we need to compute the rank of ˚ (Lee 182)
  • Because the rank is constant, it suffices to compute it at the identity In 2 GL.n; R/ (Lee 182)
  • the image of d˚In is contained in the vector space of symmetric matrices. if B 2 M.n; R/ is an arbitrary symmetric ces.  Conve  n  n matrix, then d˚In 12 B D B (Lee 182)
  • rsely, . It follows that the image of d˚In is exactly the space of symmetric matrices (Lee 182)
  • The special orthogonal group of degree n is defined as SO.n/ D O.n/  SL.n; R/  GL.n; R/ (Lee 182)
  • SO.n/ is the open subgroup of O.n/ consisting of matrices of positive determinant, and is therefore also an embedded Lie subgroup of dimension n.n  1/=2 in GL.n; R/ (Lee 182)
  • the adjoint of A is the matrix A formed by conjugating the entries of A and taking the transpose: A  D AxT (Lee 182)
  • the unitary group of degree n is the subgroup U.n/  GL.n; C/ consisting (Lee 182)
  • of complex n  n matrices whose columns form an orthonormal basis for C n with orm an P respect to the Hermitian dot product z  w D i z i w i . (Lee 183)
  • P U.n/ consists of those matrices A such that A A D In (Lee 183)
  • The group SU.n/ D U.n/  SL.n; C/ is called the complex special unitary group of degree n. (Lee 183)
  • properly embedded .n2  1/-dimensional Lie subgroup of U.n/. (Lee 183)
  • SU.n/ is also embedded in GL.n; C/. (Lee 183)
  • Suppose H and N are Lie groups, and  W H  N ! N is a smooth left action of H on N . It is said to be an action by automorphisms if for each h 2 H , the map h W N ! N is a group automorphism of N (Lee 183)
  • we define a new Lie group N Ì H , called a semidirect product of H and N , as follows (Lee 183)
  • As a smooth manifold, N Ì H is just the Cartesian product N  H ; but the group multiplication is defined by .n; h/.n0 ; h0 / D nh .n0 /; hh0 : (Lee 183)
  • action of H on N (Lee 183)
  • E.n/ D Rn Ì O.n/ is called the Euclidean group; its multiplication is given by .b; A/.b 0 ; A0 / D .b C Ab 0 ; AA0 /. It acts on Rn via .b; A/  x D b C Ax: (Lee 183)
  • then the natural action of O.n/ on Rn is an action by automorphisms (Lee 183)
  • The subsets Nz D N  feg and H z D feg  H are closed Lie subgroups of G isomorphic to N and H (Lee 183)
  • Nz is a normal subgroup of G. z (c) z z z z N  H D f.e; e/g and N H D G. (Lee 184)
  • Theorem 7.35 (Characterization of Semidirect Products). Suppose G is a Lie group, and N; H  G are closed Lie subgroups such that N is normal, N  H D feg, and NH D G. Then the map .n; h/ 7! nh is a Lie group isomorphism between N Ì H and G, where  W H  N ! N is the action by conjugation: h .n/ D hnh 1 . (Lee 184)
  • Most of the Lie groups we have seen so far can be realized as Lie subgroups of GL.n; R/ or GL.n; C/. It is natural to ask whether all Lie groups are of this form. (Lee 184)
  • If G is a Lie group, a (finitedimensional) representation of G is a Lie group homomorphism from G to GL.V / for some V (Lee 184)
  • If a representation  W G ! GL.V / is injective, it is said to be faithfu (Lee 184)
  • he image of  is a Lie subgroup of GL.V /, and  gives a Lie group isomorphism between G and .G/  GL.V / Š GL.n; R/ or GL.n; C/. (Lee 184)
  • Thus, a Lie group admits a faithful representation if and only if it is isomorphic to a Lie subgroup of GL.n; R/ or GL.n; C/ for some n (Lee 184)
  • the universal covering group of SL.2; R/ has no faithful representation and therefore is not isomorphic to any matrix group. (Lee 184)
  • f G is any Lie subgroup of GL.n; R/, the inclusion map G ,! GL.n; R/ D GL.R n / is a faithful representation, called the defining representation of G . (Lee 184)
  • inclusion map S1 ,! C  Š GL.1; C/ is a faithful representation (Lee 185)
  • sends x 2 Rn to the matrix  .x/ (Lee 185)
  •  is a faithful representation of the additive Lie group Rn (Lee 185)
  • Another faithful representation of Rn is the map Rn ! GL.n; R/ that sen x ; : : : ; x n to the diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are e x ; : : : ; e x x ; : : : ; x n to the diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are e x ; : : : ; e x (Lee 185)
  • This one is not  faithful, because its kernel is the subgroup Zn  Rn . (Lee 185)
  • A faithful representation of E.n/ is given by the map  W E.n/ ! GL.n C 1; R/ defined in block form by Ab Ab   .b; A/ D ; 01 (Lee 185)
  • define a linear map dn .A/W Pdn ! Pdn by (Lee 185)
  • vector space of real-valued polynomial functions p W Rn ! R of degree at most d (Lee 185)
  • An action of G on V is said to be a linear action if for each g 2 G, the map from V to itself given by x 7! g  x is linear (Lee 185)
  • is an associated smooth linear action of G on V given by g  x D .g/x. The next proposition shows that every linear action is of this type. (Lee 185)
  • Proposition 7.37. Let G be a Lie group and V be a finite-dimensional vector space. A smooth left action of G on V is linear if and only if it is of the form g  x D .g/x for some representation  of G. (Lee 185)
  • Every action induced by a representation is evidently linear. (Lee 186)
  • the fundamental theorem on flows, asserts that every smooth vector field determines a unique maximal integral curve starting at each point, and the collection of all such integral curves determines a unique maximal flow (Lee 220)
  • we investigate conditions under which a vector field generates a global flow (Lee 220)
  • “flowing out” from initial submanifolds along vector fields can be used to create useful parametrizations of larger submanifolds (Lee 220)
  • the behavior at points where the vector field vanishes, which correspond to equilibrium points of the flow, is very different from the behavior at points where it does not vanish, where the flow looks locally like translation along parallel coordinate lines. (Lee 220)
  • Lie derivative, which is a coordinate-independent way of computing the rate of change of one vector field along the flow of another. (Lee 220)
  • two vector fields have commuting flows if and only if their Lie bracket is zero (Lee 220)
  • necessary and sufficient condition for a smooth local frame to be expressible as a coordinate frame (Lee 220)
  • If V is a vector field on M; an integral curve of V is a differentiable curve W J ! M whose velocity at each point is equal to the value of V at that point: 0 .t/ D V .t/ for all t 2 J: (Lee 221)
  • because solving a system of ODEs is often referred to as “integrating” the system. (Lee 222)
  • For each point p 2 M; there exist " > 0 and a smooth curve W .“;”/ ! M that is an integral curve of V starting at p (Lee 222)
  • each point p 2 M; V has a unique integral curve starting at p and defined for all t 2 R, which we denote by  .p/ W R ! M . (Lee 224)
  • define a map  t W M ! M by sending each p 2 M to the point obtained by following for time t the integral curve starting at p:  t .p/ D  .p/ .t/: (Lee 224)
  •  t ı s .p/ D  tCs .p/: (Lee 224)
  • The assignment p 7! Vp is a (rough) vector field on M; which is called the infinitesimal generator of  (Lee 225)
  • every smooth global flow is derived from the integral curves of some smooth vector field (Lee 225)
  • a flow domain for M is an open subset D  R  M with the property that for each p 2 M; the set D .p/ D ft 2 R W .t; p/ 2 Dg is an open interval containing 0 (Lee 226)
  • A flow on M is a continuous map  W D ! M; where D  R  M is a flow domain, that satisfies the following group laws: for all p 2 M; .0; p/ D p; and for all s 2 D .p/ and t 2 D ..s;p// such that s C t 2 D .p/ ,  t; .s; p/ D .t C s; p/: (Lee 226)
  • We say that a smooth vector field is complete if it generates a global flow, or equivalently if each of its maximal integral curves is defined for all t 2 R (Lee 230)
  • Corollary 9.17. On a compact smooth manifold, every smooth vector field is complete. (Lee 231)
  • Theorem 9.18. Every left-invariant vector field on a Lie group is complete. (Lee 231)
  • all compactly supported smooth vector fields, and therefore all smooth vector fields on a compact manifold, are complete. (Lee 231)
  • Theorem 9.16. Every compactly supported smooth vector field on a smooth manifold is complete. (Lee 231)
  • If V is a vector field on M; a point p 2 M is said to be a singular point of V if Vp D 0, and a regular point otherwise (Lee 234)
  • The canonical form theorem shows that a flow in a neighborhood of a regular point behaves, up to diffeomorphism, just like translation along parallel coordinate lines in Rn (Lee 237)
  • Proposition 13.3 (Existence of Riemannian Metrics). Every smooth manifold with or without boundary admits a Riemannian metric. (Lee 344)
  • Stokes’s Theorem (Lee 426)
  • Theorem 16.11 (Stokes’s Theorem). Let M be an oriented smooth n-manifold with boundary, and let ! be a compactly supported smooth .n  1/-form on M . Then Z d! D !: (16.4) M @M (Lee 426)
  • The pth compactly supported de Rham cohomology group of M is the quotient space .M /  p Ker d W pc .M / ! pC1 c .M / H   p c .M / D Im d W  p1 c .M / ! pc .M / (Lee 468)
  • Theorem 17.28 (Compactly Supported Cohomology of Rn ). For n  1, the compactly supported de Rham cohomology groups of Rn are ( p n 0 if 0  p < n; H p n c .R / Š R if p D n: (Lee 468)
  • In general, a smooth map need not pull back compactly supported forms to compactly supported ones, so it does not induce a map on compactly supported cohomology. (Lee 468)
  • One important application is the Poincaré duality theorem, which is outlined in Problem 18-7. (Lee 469)
  • Another application is to facilitate the computation of de Rham cohomology in the top degree. (Lee 469)
  • symplectic structure, which is superficially similar to a Riemannian metric (Lee 579)
  • nondegeneracy is important because it yields a tangentcotangent isomorphism like that provided by a Riemannian metric (Lee 579)
  • closedness is important because it leads to a deep relationship between smooth functions and flows (Lee 579)
  • canonically defined symplectic structure on the cotangent bundle of each smooth manifold (Lee 579)
  • Darboux theorem, which shows that every symplectic form can be put into canonical form locally by a choice of smooth coordinates, so, unlike the situation for Riemannian metrics, there is no local obstruction to “flatness” of symplectic structures (Lee 579)
  • Any smooth real-valued function on a symplectic manifold gives rise to a canonical system of ordinary differential equations called a Hamiltonian system. (Lee 579)
  • symplectic and contact geometry can be used to construct solutions to first-order partial differential equations. (Lee 579)
  • 2n, with a basis denoted by ˛ 1 ; ˇ 1 ; : : : ; ˛ n ; ˇ n Example 22.2. Let V be a .A1 ; B1 ; : : : ; An ; Bn /. Let ˛ vector space of dimension 1 ; ˇ 1 ; : : : ; ˛ n ; ˇ n denote the corresponding dual basis  for V  , and let ! 2 ƒ2 .V  / be the 2-covector defined by n X !D ˛i ^ ˇi : (Lee 580)
  • Thus ! is nondegenerate, and so is a symplectic tensor. (Lee 580)
  • Symplectic complements differ from orthogonal complements in one important respect: although it is always true that S  S ? D f0g in an inner product space, this need not be true in a symplectic vector space (Lee 581)
  • ! is alternating forces !.v; v/ D 0 for every v 2 S , so S  S ? (Lee 581)
  •  symplectic if S  S ? D f0g;  isotropic if S  S ? ;  coisotropic if S  S ? ;  Lagrangian if S D S ? . (Lee 581)
  • S is Lagrangian if and only if !jS D 0 and dim S D 21 dim V . (Lee 581)
  • The symplectic tensor ! defined in Example 22.2 turns out to be the prototype of all symplectic tensors (Lee 581)
  • This can be viewed as a symplectic version of the Gram–Schmidt algorithm. Proposition 22.7 (Canonical Form for a Symplectic Tensor). Let ! be a symplectic tensor on an m-dimensional vector space V . Then V has even dimension m D 2n, and there exists a basis for V in which ! has the form (22.1 (Lee 581)
  • Proposition 22.8. Suppose V is a 2n-dimensional vector space and ! 2 ƒ2 .V  /. Then ! is a symplectic tensor if and only if ! n ¤ 0. (Lee 582)
  • If .M1 ; !1 / and .M2 ; !2 / are symplectic manifolds, a diffeomorphism F W M1 ! M 2 satisfying F  !2 D !1 is called a symplectomorphism (Lee 583)
  • X !D dx i ^ dy (Lee 583)
  • This is called the standard 2 n symplectic form on R2 n (Lee 583)
  • Suppose ˙ is any orientable smooth 2-manifold and ! is a nonvanishing smooth 2-form on ˙ . (Lee 583)
  • so .˙; !/ is a symplectic manifold. (Lee 583)
  • An (immersed or embedded) submanifold S  M is said to be a symplectic, isotropic, coisotropic, or Lagrangian submanifold if Tp S (thought of as a subspace of Tp M ) has the corresponding property at each point p 2 S (Lee 583)
  • Clearly, ! is closed, because it is exact (Lee 585)
  •  W M ! T  M is playing two roles: on the one hand, it is a 1-form on M; and on the other hand, it is a smooth map between manifolds (Lee 585)
  • Proposition 22.12. Let M be a smooth manifold, and let  be a smooth 1-form on M . Thought of as a smooth map from M to T  M;  is a smooth embedding, and  is closed if and only if its image  .M / is a Lagrangian submanifold of T  M . (Lee 585)
  • It is a nonlinear analogue of the canonical form for a symplectic tensor (Lee 586)
  • the most dramatic difference between symplectic structures and Riemannian metrics: unlike the Riemannian case, there is no local obstruction to a symplectic structure being locally equivalent to the standard flat model. (Lee 586)
