  • we obtain the product. (Ravi Vakil 40)
  • If I is a set (i.e., the only morphisms are∏the identity maps), then the limit is ∏t called the product of the Ai , and is denoted i Ai . The special case where I has two elements is the example of the previous paragraph. (Ravi Vakil 40)
  • 1.4.A. E XERCISE ( REALITY CHECK ). Suppose that the partially ordered set I has an initial object e. Show that the limit of any diagram indexed by I exists. (Ravi Vakil 40)
  • 1.4.3. Example: the p-adic integers. For a prime number p, the p-adic integers (or more informally, p-adics), Zp , are often described informally (and somewhat (Ravi Vakil 40)
  • Zp = a0 + a1 p + a2 p2 + · · · (where 0 ≤ ai < p). (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • They are an example of a limit in the category of rings: (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • The p-adic integers are an example of a completion, the topic of Chapter 29 (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • Limits do not always exist for any index category I . However, you can often easily check that limits exist if the objects of your category can be interpreted as sets with additional structure, and arbitrary products exist (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • 1.4.B. I MPORTANT E XERCISE . Show that in the category Sets, (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • along with the obvious projection maps to each Ai , is the limit lim Ai . ←− (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • From this point of view, 2 + 3p + 2p2 + · · · ∈ Zp can be understood as the sequence (2, 2 + 3p, 2 + 3p + 2p2 , . . . ). (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • More immediately relevant for us will be the dual (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • colimit, which is denoted limI A −→ (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • (In some cases, the colimit is sometimes called the direct limit, inductive limit, or injective limit. (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • Also, I remember that kernels “map to”, and cokernels are “mapped to”, which reminds me that a limit maps to all the objects in the big commutative diagram indexed by I ; and a colimit has a map from all the objects. (Ravi Vakil 41)
  • 1.4.6. Example. The set 5−∞ Z of rational numbers whose denominators are powers of 5 is a colimit lim 5−i Z. More precisely, 5−∞ Z is the colimit of the diagram −→ lim −→ Z / 5−1 Z / 5−2 Z / ··· ⨿ The colimit over an index set I is called the coproduct, denoted i Ai , and is the dual (arrow-reversed) notion to the product. (Ravi Vakil 42)
  • 1 (a) Interpret the statement “Q = lim n −→ Z”. lim −→ (Ravi Vakil 42)
  • lim −→ (b) Interpret the union of some subsets of a given set as a colimit. (Dually, the intersection can be interpreted as a limit.) (Ravi Vakil 42)
  • A nonempty partially ordered set (S, ≥) is filtered (or is said to be a filtered set) if for each x, y ∈ S, there is a z such that x ≥ z and y ≥ z. More generally, a nonempty category I is filtered if: (i) for each x, y ∈ I , there is a z ∈ I and arrows x → z and y → z, and (ii) for every two arrows u : x → y and v : x → y, there is an arrow w : y → z such that w ◦ u = w ◦ v. (Ravi Vakil 42)
  • Show that any diagram in Sets indexed by I has the following, with the obvious maps to it, as a colimit: (Ravi Vakil 42)
  • For instance, 17/125 is an element of the 5−3 Z (or 5−4 Z, or later ones), but not 5−2 Z. (Ravi Vakil 42)
  • each element of the colimit is an element of something upstairs, but you can’t say in advance what it is an element of. F (Ravi Vakil 42)
  • For example, the colimit lim Mi in the category of A-modules ModA can be described −→ as follows. The set underlying lim Mi is defined as in Exercise 1.4.D. To add the −→ elements mi ∈ Mi and mj ∈ Mj , choose an ℓ ∈ I with arrows u : i → ℓ and v : j → ℓ, and then define the sum of mi and mj to be F(u)(mi ) + F(v)(mj ) ∈ Mℓ . The element mi ∈ Mi is 0 if and only if there is some arrow u : i → k for which F(u)(m i ) = 0, i.e., if it becomes 0 “later in the diagram”. Last, multiplication by an element of A is defined in the obvious way. (Ravi Vakil 42)
  • Verify that the A-module described above is indeed the colimit. (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • Make sure you verify that addition is well-defined, i.e., is independent of the choice of representatives mi and mj , the choice of ℓ, and the choice of arrows u and v. Similarly, make sure that scalar multiplication is well-defined (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • Show that the colimit is ⊕i∈I Mi modulo the relations m i −F(n)(mi ) for every n : i → j in I (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • nterpret localization of an integral domain as a colimit over a filtered set (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • Can you make some version of this work even if A isn’t an integral domain, (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • works without the filtered condition, if you have another means of “connecting elements in different objects of your diagram” (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • In a category where the objects are “set-like”, an element of a limit can be thought of as a family of elements of each object in the diagram, that are “compatible” (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • And an element of a colimit can be thought of (“has a representative that is”) an element of a single object in the diagram (Exercise 1.4.D). Even though the definitions of limit and colimit are the same, just with arrows reversed, these interpretations are quite different. (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • Two covariant functors F : A → B and G : B → A are adjoint if there is a natural bijection for all A ∈ A and B ∈ B (1.5.0.1) τAB : MorB (F(A), B) → MorA (A, G(B)). (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • We say that (F, G) form an adjoint pair, and that F is left-adjoint to G (and G is right-adjoint to F). We say F is a left adjoint (and G is a right adjoint) (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • By “natural” (Ravi Vakil 43)
  • we mean the following. For all f : A → A ′ in A , we require (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • o commute, and for all g : B → B ′ in B we want a similar commutative diagram to commute. (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • (Here f∗ is the map induced by f : A → A ′ , and Ff∗ is the map induced by Ff : F(A) → F(A ′ ).) (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • Write down what this diagram should be. (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • how that the map τAB (1.5.0.1) has the following properties. (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • For each A there is a map ηA : A → GF(A) so that for any g : F(A) → B, the corresponding τAB (g) : A → G(B) is given by the composition ηA A / GF(A) Gg / G(B). (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • Similarly, there is a map ϵB : FG(B) → B for each B so that for any f : A → G(B), −1 the corresponding map τAB (f) : F(A) → B is given by the composition Ff F(A) / FG(B) ϵB / B. (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • Suppose M, N, and P are A-modules (where A is a ring). Describe a bijection HomA (M ⊗A N, P) ↔︎ HomA (M, HomA (N, P)). (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • . Show that (·) ⊗A N and HomA (N, ·) are adjoint functors. (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • Show that this functor is right-adjoint to · ⊗B A. (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • describe a bijection ∼ HomA (N ⊗B A, M) = ∼ HomB (N, MB ) = (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • functorial in both arguments. (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • You can check that the left adjoint determines the right adjoint up to natural isomorphism, and vice versa. (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • The maps η A and ϵB of Exercise 1.5.B are called the unit and counit of the adjunction (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • This leads to a different characterization of adjunction. Suppose functors F : A → B and G : B → A are given, along with natural transformations η : idA → GF and ϵ : FG → idB with the property that Gϵ ◦ ηG = idG (for each B ∈ B, the composition of ηG(B) : G(B) → GFG(B) and G(ϵB ) : GFG(B) → G(B) is the identity) and ϵF ◦ Fη = idF . Then you can check that F is left-adjoint to G (Ravi Vakil 44)
  • 1.5.2. Examples from other fields. For those familiar with representation theory: Frobenius reciprocity may be understood in terms of adjoints. Suppose V is a finite-dimensional representation of a finite group G, and W is a representation of a subgroup H < G. Then induction and restriction are an adjoint pair (IndG G H , ResH ) between the category of G-modules and the category of H-modules. (Ravi Vakil 45)
  • Topologists’ favorite adjoint pair may be the suspension functor and the loop space functor. (Ravi Vakil 45)
  • A groupification of a semigroup S is a map of abelian semigroups π : S → G such that G is an abelian ′ group, and any map of abelian semigroups from S to an abelian group G ′ factors uniquely through G (Ravi Vakil 45)
  • Show that if an abelian semigroup is already a group then the identity morphism is the groupification. (Ravi Vakil 45)
  • Construct the “groupification functor” H from the category of nonempty abelian semigroups to the category of abelian groups (Ravi Vakil 45)
  • Other examples will also come up, such as the adjoint pair (∼, Γ• ) between graded modules over a graded ring, and quasicoherent sheaves on the corresponding projective scheme (Ravi Vakil 46)
  • Here is a table of most of the adjoints that will come up for us. (Ravi Vakil 46)
  • 1.6.1. Definition. A category C is said to be additive if it satisfies the following properties. Ad1. For each A, B ∈ C , Mor(A, B) is an abelian group, such that composition of morphisms distributes over addition. (You should think about what this means — it translates to two distinct statements.) Ad2. C has a zero object, denoted 0. (This is an object that is simultaneously an initial object and a final object, Definition 1.3.2.) Ad3. It has products of two objects (a product A × B for any pair of objects), and hence by induction, products of any finite number of objects. (Ravi Vakil 47)
  • If (F, G) is an adjoint pair of functors, then F commutes with colimits, and G commutes with limits. (Ravi Vakil 47)
  • Also, limits commute with limits and colimits commute with colimits. (Ravi Vakil 47)
  • A functor between additive categories preserving the additive structure of Hom, is called an additive functor. (Ravi Vakil 48)
  • An abelian category is an additive category satisfying three additional properties. (1) Every map has a kernel and cokernel. (2) Every monomorphism is the kernel of its cokernel. (3) Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel. (Ravi Vakil 48)
  • A kernel of a morphism f : B → C is a map i : A → B such that f ◦ i = 0, and that is universal with respect to this property. (Ravi Vakil 48)
  • A cokernel (denoted coker f) is defined dually by reversing the arrows — do this yourself. (Ravi Vakil 48)
  • The cokernel of a monomorphism is called the quotient (Ravi Vakil 49)
  • The image of a morphism f : A → B is defined as im(f) = ker(coker f) (Ravi Vakil 49)
  • is a complex at B if g ◦ f = 0, and is exact at B if ker g = im f. (Ravi Vakil 49)
  • (More specifically, g has a kernel that is an image of f. Exactness at B implies being a complex at B (Ravi Vakil 49)
  • we will show that sheaves of abelian groups on a topological space X form an abelian category (Ravi Vakil 49)
  • If (1.6.5.1) is a complex at B, then its homology at B (often denoted by H) is ker g / im f. (Ravi Vakil 50)
  • , there is some monomorphism im f ,→ ker g, and that H is the cokernel of this monomorphism (Ravi Vakil 50)
  • homology is “cycles mod boundaries” (Ravi Vakil 50)
  • Therefore, (1.6.5.1) is exact at B if and only if its homology at B is 0. (Ravi Vakil 50)
  • We say that elements of ker g (Ravi Vakil 50)
  • are the cycles, and elements of im f are the boundaries (Ravi Vakil 50)
  • at Ai−1 → Ai → Ai+1 is often called cohomology. An exact sequence (1.6.5.2) A• : ··· / Ai−1 fi−1 / Ai fi / Ai+1 fi+1 / ··· can be “factored” into short exact sequences 0 / ker fi / Ai / ker fi+1 /0 (Ravi Vakil 50)
  • Describe exact sequences (Ravi Vakil 51)
  • Define h (A i • ) := dim H (A i ).∑Show that (−1) dim A = (−1) hi (A• ). In par• i i ∑S ticular, if A• is exact, then (−1)i dim Ai = 0 (Ravi Vakil 51)
  • Suppose C is an abelian category. Define the category ComC of complexes as follows. The objects are infinite complexes (Ravi Vakil 51)
  • in C , and the morphisms A• → B• are commuting diagrams (Ravi Vakil 51)
  • Show that ComC is an abelian category (Ravi Vakil 51)
  • 1.6.D. I MPORTANT E XERCISE . Show that (1.6.5.5) induces a map of homology H i (A• ) → Hi (B• ). Show furthermore that Hi is a covariant functor ComC → C (Ravi Vakil 51)
  • 1.6.6. Theorem (Long exact sequence). — A short exact sequence of complexes (Ravi Vakil 52)
  • induces a long exact sequence in cohomology (Ravi Vakil 52)
  • If F : A → B is a covariant additive functor from one abelian category to another, we say that F is right-exact if the exactness of A′ /A / A ′′ / 0, in A implies that F(A ′ ) / F(A) / F(A ′′ ) /0 is also exact. Dually, we say that F is left-exact if the exactness of 0 / A′ /A / A ′′ implies 0 / F(A ′ ) / F(A) / F(A ′′ ) is exact. (Ravi Vakil 52)
  • 1.6.E. E XERCISE . Suppose F is an exact functor. Show that applying F to an exact sequence preserves exactness. (Ravi Vakil 53)
  • 1.6.F. E XERCISE . Suppose A is a ring, S ⊂ A is a multiplicative subset, and M is an A-module. (a) Show that localization of A-modules ModA → ModS−1 A is an exact covariant functor. (b) Show that (·) ⊗A M is a right-exact covariant functor ModA → ModA . (This is a repeat of Exercise 1.3.H.) (c) Show that Hom(M, ·) is a left-exact covariant functor ModA → ModA . If C is any abelian category, and C ∈ C , show that Hom(C, ·) is a left-exact covariant functor C → Ab. (d) Show that Hom(·, M) is a left-exact contravariant functor ModA → ModA . If C is any abelian category, and C ∈ C , show that Hom(·, C) is a left-exact contravariant functor C → Ab. (Ravi Vakil 53)
  • Suppose M is a finitely presented A-module: M has a finite number of generators, and with these generators it has a finite number of relations; or usefully equivalently, fits in an exact sequence (1.6.7.1) A ⊕q → A⊕p → M → 0 (Ravi Vakil 53)
  • Use (1.6.7.1) and the left-exactness of Hom to describe an isomorphism S ∼ HomS−1 A (S−1 M, S−1 N). −1 HomA (M, N) = (Ravi Vakil 53)
  • 1.6.8. Example: Hom doesn’t always commute with localization. (Ravi Vakil 53)
  • A contravariant functor is left-exact if the exactness of A′ /A / A ′′ /0 implies 53 0 / F(A ′′ ) / F(A) / F(A ′ ) is exact. (Ravi Vakil 53)
  • 1.6.H. I MPORTANT E XERCISE ( THE FHHF T HEOREM ) (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • (F right-exact yields FH• / H• F ) (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • ) (F left-exact yields FH• o H• F ) (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • (F exact yields FH• o ∼ / H• F (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • If F is right-exact, describe a natural morphism FH • • → H F. (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • If F is left-exact, describe a natural morphism H • F → FH • (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • If F is exact, show that the morphisms of (a) and (b) are inverses and thus isomorphisms. (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • If ⊗N is exact, then N is called a flat A-module. (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • localization is exact (Exercise 1.6.F(a)), so S−1 A is a flat A-algebra for all multiplicative sets S. Thus taking cohomology of a complex of A-modules commutes with localization (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • Limits commute with limits and right adjoints. In particular, in an abelian category, because kernels are limits, both right adjoints and limits are left-exact. (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • Colimits commute with colimits and left adjoints. In particular, because cokernels are colimits, both left adjoints and colimits are right-exact. (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • In ModA , colimits over filtered index categories are exact. (Ravi Vakil 54)
  • E XERCISE ( KERNELS COMMUTE WITH LIMITS ). (Ravi Vakil 55)
  • E XERCISE . Make sense of the statement that “limits commute with limits” in a general category, and prove it (Ravi Vakil 55)
  • Proposition (right adjoints commute with limits). — Suppose (F : C → D, G : D → C ) is a pair of adjoint functors. If A = lim Ai is a limit in D of a diagram ←− lim ←− indexed by I , then GA = lim GAi (with the corresponding maps GA → GAi ) is a limit ←− lim ←− in C . (Ravi Vakil 55)
  • E XERCISE . Show that in ModA , colimits over filtered index categories are exact. (Ravi Vakil 55)
  • Show that filtered colimits commute with homology in ModA . (Ravi Vakil 56)
  • Are limits analogous to leftexact functors, or right-exact functors? (Ravi Vakil 56)
  • Based on these ideas, you may suspect that rightexact functors always commute with colimits. The fact that tensor product commutes with infinite direct sums (Exercise 1.3.M) may reinforce this idea. Unfortunately, it is not true — “double dual” ·∨∨ : Veck → Veck is covariant and right exact (why is it right-exact?), but does not commute with infinite direct sums, as ⊕ ∞ i=1 (k ∨∨ ) is not isomorphic to (⊕∞ i=1 k) ∨∨ . (Ravi Vakil 56)
  • Dreaming of derived functors (Ravi Vakil 57)
  • we have a “restriction map” resV,U : O(V) → O(U). (Ravi Vakil 71)
  • We denote this ring of functions O(U). (Ravi Vakil 71)
  • In other words, if U ,→ V ,→ W, then the following diagram commutes: resW,V O(W) / O(V) ) HH HH HH resW,U H H H # # {ww ww wwresV,U w ww res w w O(U) (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • We say {Ui } covers U, or is an open cover of U, if U = ∪U (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • Suppose that f1 and f2 agree on each of these U i . Then they must have been the same function to begin with. (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • Next take two differentiable functions f1 and f2 on a big open set U, and an open cover of U by some collection of open subsets {Ui }. ( (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • In other words, given f i ∈ O(Ui ) for all i, such that resUi ,Ui ∩Uj fi = resUj ,Ui ∩Uj fj for all i and j, then there is some f ∈ O(U) such that resU,Ui f = fi for all i. (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • the germ of a differentiable function at a point p ∈ X (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • Germs are objects of the form {(f, open U) : p ∈ U, f ∈ O(U)} (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • modulo the relation that (f, U) ∼ (g, V) if there is some open set W ⊂ U, V containing p where f|W = g|W (i.e., resU,W f = resV,W g). (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • In other words, two functions that are the same in an open neighborhood of p (but may differ elsewhere) have the same germ (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • We call this set of germs the stalk at p, and denote it Op (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • Notice that the stalk is a ring: (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • Notice also that if p ∈ U, you get a map O(U) → Op . Experts may already see that we are talking about germs as colimits. (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • Op is a local ring as follows (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • Consider those germs vanishing at p, which we denote mp ⊂ Op (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • We check that this ideal is maximal by showing that the quotient ring is a field: (Ravi Vakil 72)
  • 2.1.A. E XERCISE . Show that this is the only maximal ideal of Op . (Hint: show that every element of Op  mp is invertible.) (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • we can interpret the value of a function at a point, or the value of a germ at a point, as an element of the local ring modulo the maximal ideal. (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • Notice that mp /m2p is a module over ∼ Op /mp = ∼ R, i.e., it is a real vector = space. It turns out to be naturally (whatever that means) the cotangent space to the smooth manifold at p (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • 2.1.B. ⋆ E XERCISE FOR THOSE WITH DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRIC BACKGROUND . Prove this. (Rhetorical question for experts: what goes wrong if the sheaf of continuous functions is substituted for the sheaf of differentiable functions?) (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • The fact that F is a sheaf on a topological space X is often written as F X (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • 2.2.2. Definition: Presheaf. A presheaf F on a topological space X is the following data. (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • To each open set U ⊂ X, we have a set F (U) (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • F (U) = Γ (U, F ) = H0 (U, F ) (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • The elements of F (U) are called sections of F over U (Ravi Vakil 73)
  • By convention, if the “U” is omitted, it is implicitly taken to be X: “sections of F” means “sections of F over X”. These are also called global sections. (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • For each inclusion U ,→ V of open sets, we have a restriction map resV,U : F (V) → F (U) (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • .2.A. E XERCISE FOR CATEGORYLOVERS : “A PRESHEAF IS THE SAME AS A CON TRAVARIANT FUNCTOR”. Given any topological space X, we have a “category of open sets” (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • Verify that the data of a presheaf is precisely the data of a contravariant functor from the category of open sets of X to the category of sets. (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • Define the stalk of a presheaf F at a point p to be the set of germs of F at p, denoted Fp (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • A useful equivalent definition of a stalk is as a colimit of all F (U) over all open sets U containing p: Fp = lim F (U). −→ lim −→ (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • The index category is a filtered set (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • More precisely: the stalk is {(f, open U) : p ∈ U, f ∈ F (U)} modulo the relation that (f, U) ∼ (g, V) if there is some open set W ⊂ U, V where p ∈ W and resU,W f = resV,W g. (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • If p ∈ U, and f ∈ F (U), then the image of f in Fp is called the germ of f at p. (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • the value of a section at a point doesn’t make sense. (Ravi Vakil 74)
  • Definition: Sheaf. A presheaf is a sheaf if it satisfies two more axioms. (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • Identity axiom. If {Ui }i∈I is an open cover of U, and f1 , f2 ∈ F (U), and resU,U i f1 = resU,Ui f2 for all i, then f1 = f2 . (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • Gluability axiom. If {Ui }i∈I is an open cover of U, then given fi ∈ F (Ui ) for all i, such that resUi ,Ui ∩Uj fi = resUj ,Ui ∩Uj fj for all i, j, then there is some f ∈ F (U) such that resU,Ui f = fi for all i. (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • identity means there is at most one way to glue, and gluability means that there is at least one way to glue. (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • F (∅) is required to be the final object in the category. (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • If U and V are disjoint, then F (U ∪ V) = F (U) × F (V). (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • the fact that F (∅) is the final object. (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • Here we use (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • The two axioms for a presheaf to be a sheaf can be interpreted as “exactness” of the “equalizer exact sequence”: · / F (U) nterpreted as “exactness” of the “equalizer exact / ∏ F (Ui ) // ∏ F (U ∩ U ). Identity is exacti j ∏ ness at F (U), and gluability is exactness at F (Ui ). (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • 2.2.C. E XERCISE . The identity and gluability axioms may be interpreted as saying that F (∪i∈I Ui ) is a certain limit. What is that limit? (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • 2.2.D. E XERCISE . (a) Verify that the examples of §2.1 are indeed sheaves (of differentiable functions, or continuous functions, or smooth functions, or functions on a manifold or Rn ). (b) Show that real-valued continuous functions on (open sets of) a topological space X form a sheaf. (Ravi Vakil 75)
  • Suppose F is a sheaf on X, and U is an open subset of X. Define the restriction of F to U, denoted F |U , to be the collection F |U (V) = F (V) for all open subsets V ⊂ U (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • This is called a skyscraper sheaf, (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • Suppose X is a topological space, with p ∈ X, and S is a set. Let ip : p → X be the inclusion. Then ip,∗ S defined by { S if p ∈ U, and i p,∗ S(U) = {e} if p ∈ /U forms a sheaf. Here {e} is any one-element set. (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • suggests that the only nontrivial stalk of a skyscraper sheaf is at p, which isn’t the case (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • i p,∗ S(U) should be a final object. (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • This is called the constant presheaf associated to S. (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • This isn’t (in general) a sheaf. (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • This is called the constant sheaf (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • We denote this sheaf S. (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • S pre f (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • Define Spre (U) = S for all open sets U. (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • let F (U) be the maps to S that are locally constant, i.e., for any point p in U, there is an open neighborhood of p where the function is constant. (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • Let X be a topological space, and S a set. (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • 2.2.E. E XERCISE ( CONSTANT SHEAVES ). (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • 2.2.8. Important Example: (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • 2.2.9. Important Example: (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • 2.2.F. E XERCISE (“ MORPHISMS GLUE ”). Suppose Y is a topological space. Show that “continuous maps to Y” form a sheaf of sets on X (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • 2.2.G. E XERCISE . (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • Suppose we are given a continuous map µ : Y → X. Show that “sections of µ” form a sheaf. More precisely, to each open set U of X, associate the set of continuous maps s : U → Y such that µ ◦ s = id|U . (Ravi Vakil 76)
  • The topological space F could be thought of as the space of sections of F (and in French is called the espace étalé of F ). (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • Suppose F is a presheaf (e.g., a sheaf) on a topological space X. Construct a topological space F along with a continuous map π : F → X as follows: as a set, F is the disjoint union of all the stalks of F (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • Topologize F as follows. Each s in F (U) determines a subset {(x, sx ) : x ∈ U} of F. The topology on F is the weakest topology such that these subsets are open. (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • This is called the pushforward or direct image of F (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • define π∗ F by π∗ F (V) = F (π−1 (V)) (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • π : X → Y is a continuous map, and F is a presheaf on X. (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • 2.2.H. I MPORTANT E XERCISE /D EFINITION : (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • Show that π∗ F is a presheaf on Y, and is a sheaf if F is. (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • the skyscraper sheaf (Example 2.2.9) can be interpreted as the pushforward of the constant sheaf S on a one-point space p, under the inclusion morphism ip : {p} → X. (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • pushforward is a functor from sheaves on X to sheaves on Y (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • 2.2.I. E XERCISE (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • If π(p) = q, describe the natural morphism of stalks (π∗ F )q → Fp (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • Suppose OX is a sheaf of rings on a topological space X (i.e., a sheaf on X with values in the category of Rings). Then (X, OX ) is called a ringed space. The sheaf of rings is often denoted by OX , pronounced “oh-X”. This sheaf is called the structure sheaf of the ringed space. Sections of the structure sheaf OX over an open subset U are called functions on U. (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • “regular functions” (Ravi Vakil 77)
  • The symbol OX will always refer to the structure sheaf of a ringed space X. (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • call (U, OU ) → (X, OX ) an open embedding of ringed spaces (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • The stalk of OX at a point p is written “OX,p” (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • we have OX -modules over a sheaf of rings OX . (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • OX module — a sheaf of abelian groups F with the following additional structure. For each U, F (U) is an OX (U)-module. Furthermore, this structure should behave well with respect to restriction maps: if U ⊂ V, then (2.2.13.1) OX (V) × F (V) res V,U × resV,U OX (U) × F (U) action / F (V) resV,U action / F (U (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • A-module generalizes the notion of abelian group, because an abelian group is the same thing as a Z-module. Similarly, the notion of OX -module generalizes the notion of sheaf of abelian groups, because the latter is the same thing as a Z-module, where Z is the constant sheaf associated to Z. (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • 2.2.J. E XERCISE . (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • The motivating example of OX modules is the sheaf of sections of a vector bundle. (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • A morphism of presheaves of sets (or indeed of presheaves with values in any category) on X, ϕ : F → G , is the data of maps ϕ(U) : F (U) → G (U) for all U (Ravi Vakil 78)
  • behaving well with respect to restriction: if U ,→ V then F (V) ϕ(V) / G (V) res V,U resV,U ϕ(U) F (U) ϕ(U) / G (U) commutes (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • Morphisms of sheaves are defined identically: the morphisms from a sheaf F to a sheaf G are precisely the morphisms from F to G as presheaves. (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • If (X, OX ) is a ringed space, then morphisms of OX -modules have the obvious definition. (Can you write it down?) (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • An example of a morphism of sheaves is the map from the sheaf of differentiable functions on R to the sheaf of continuous functions (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • let SetsX , AbX , etc. denote the category of sheaves of sets, abelian groups, etc. on a topological space X (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • Mod OX denote the category of OX -modules on a ringed space (X, OX ). Let pre SetsX , etc. denote the category of presheaves of sets, etc. on X. (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • If you interpret a presheaf on X as a contravariant functor (from the category of open sets), a morphism of presheaves on X is a natural transformation of functors (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • If ϕ : F → G is a morphism of presheaves on X, and p ∈ X, describe an induced morphism of stalks ϕp : Fp → Gp (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • Translation: taking the stalk at p induces a functor SetsX → Sets. (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • Show that pushforward gives a functor π∗ : SetsX → SetsY (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • 2.3.B. E XERCISE . Suppose π : X → Y is a continuous map of topological spaces (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • 2.3.C. I MPORTANT E XERCISE AND D EFINITION : “S HEAF Hom”. Suppose F and G are two sheaves of sets on X (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • Let Hom (F , G ) be the collection of data Hom (F , G )(U) := Mor(F |U , G |U ). (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • Show that this is a sheaf of sets on X (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • This sheaf is called “sheaf Hom” (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • we should reserve Hom for when we are in an additive category, so this should possibly be called “sheaf Mor”. (Ravi Vakil 79)
  • Hom does not commute with taking stalks. More precisely: it is not true that Hom (F , G )p is isomorphic to Hom(Fp , Gp ). (Ravi Vakil 80)
  • Hom AbX (F , G ) is defined by taking Hom AbX (F , G )(U) to be the maps as sheaves of abelian groups F |U → G |U (Ravi Vakil 80)
  • We call Hom ModOX (F , OX ) the dual of the OX -module F , and denote it F ∨ . (Ravi Vakil 80)
  • module-like constructions using presheaves of abelian groups on a topological space X (Ravi Vakil 80)
  • presheaves of abelian groups form an additive category (Ravi Vakil 80)
  • the morphisms between any two presheaves of abelian groups form an abelian group; there is a 0-object; and one can take finite products (Ravi Vakil 80)
  • sheaves of abelian groups also form an additive category. (Ravi Vakil 80)
  • If ϕ : F → G is a morphism of presheaves, define the presheaf kernel kerpre ϕ by (kerpre ϕ)(U) := ker ϕ(U). (Ravi Vakil 80)
  • 2.3.E. E XERCISE . Show that kerpre ϕ is a presheaf. (Ravi Vakil 81)
  • Define the presheaf cokernel cokerpre ϕ similarly. (Ravi Vakil 81)
  • 2.3.F. E XERCISE : THE COKERNEL DESERVES ITS NAME . Show that the presheaf cokernel satisfies the universal property of cokernels (Ravi Vakil 81)
  • all abelian-categorical notions may be defined and verified “open set by open set” (Ravi Vakil 81)
  • 2.3.G. E ASY E XERCISE . Show (or observe) that for a topological space X with open set U, F 7→ F (U) gives a functor from presheaves of abelian groups on X, pre AbX , to abelian groups, Ab. Then show that this functor is exact. (Ravi Vakil 81)
  • 2.3.H. E XERCISE . Show that a sequence of presheaves 0 → F1 → F2 → · · · → Fn → 0 is exact if and only if 0 → F1 (U) → F2 (U) → · · · → Fn (U) → 0 is exact for all U. (Ravi Vakil 81)
  • 2.3.I. I MPORTANT E XERCISE . Suppose ϕ : F → G is a morphism of sheaves. Show that the presheaf kernel kerpre ϕ is in fact a sheaf. Show that it satisfies the universal property of kernels (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • Thus if ϕ is a morphism of sheaves, we define ker ϕ := kerpre ϕ. (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • 2.3.J. I MPORTANT E XERCISE .   • Show that F is not a sheaf. (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • t lots of facts about sheaves can be checked “at the level of stalks” (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • This isn’t true for presheaves, and reflects the local nature of sheaves. (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • We will see that sections and morphisms are determined “by their stalks”, and the property of a morphism being an isomorphism may be checked at stalks. (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • 2.4.A. I MPORTANT EASY EXERCISE (sections are determined by germs). Prove that a section of a sheaf of sets is determined by its germs, i.e., the natural map ∏ (2.4.1.1) F (U) → Fp p∈U is injective (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • 2: it is false for presheaves in general (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • Suppose F is a sheaf (or indeed separated presheaf) of abelian groups on X, (Ravi Vakil 82)
  • and s is a global section of F . Then let the support of s, denoted Supp(s), be the points p of X where s has a nonzero germ: Supp(s) := {p ∈ X : sp ̸= 0 in Fp }. (Ravi Vakil 83)
  • We think of this as the subset of X where “the section s lives” — the complement is the locus where s is the 0-section (Ravi Vakil 83)
  • 2.4.B. E XERCISE ( THE SUPPORT OF A SECTION IS CLOSED ). a closed subset of X. (Ravi Vakil 83)
  • ∏ 2.4.3. Important definition. We say that an element p∈U sp of the right side ∏ p∈U Fp of (2.4.1.1) consists of compatible germs if for all p ∈ U, there is some representative (U p open in U, s̃p ∈ F (Up )) for sp (where p ∈ Up ⊂ U) such that the germ of s̃p at all q ∈ Up is sq (Ravi Vakil 83)
  • Equivalently, there is an open cover {Ui } of U, and sections fi ∈ F (Ui ), such that if p ∈ Ui , then sp is the germ of fi at p (Ravi Vakil 83)
  • 2.4.C. I MPORTANT E XERCISE . Prove that any choice of compatible germs for a sheaf of sets F over U is the image of a section of F over U (Ravi Vakil 83)
  • terminology “sheaf”: it is (the data of) a bunch of stalks, bundled together appropriately. (Ravi Vakil 83)
  • 2.4.D. E XERCISE (morphisms are determined by stalks). If ϕ1 and ϕ2 are morphisms from a presheaf of sets F to a sheaf of sets G that induce the same maps on each stalk, show that ϕ1 = ϕ2 (Ravi Vakil 83)

  • Note: this question does not say that if two sheaves have isomorphic stalks, then they are isomorphic. (Ravi Vakil 84)

  • (General hint for finding counterexamples of this sort: consider a 2-point space with the discrete topology.) (Ravi Vakil 84)
  • Every sheaf is a presheaf (and indeed by definition sheaves on X form a full subcategory of the category of presheaves on X) (Ravi Vakil 84)
  • One possible example to keep in mind is the sheafification of the presheaf of holomorphic functions admitting a square root on C with the classical topology. See also the exponential exact sequence, Exercise 2.4.10.) (Ravi Vakil 84)
  • 2.4.6. Definition. If F is a presheaf on X, then a morphism of presheaves sh : F → F sh on X is a sheafification of F if F sh is a sheaf, and for any sheaf G , and any presheaf morphism g : F → G , there exists a unique morphism of sheaves f : F sh → G making the diagram (Ravi Vakil 84)
  • commute. (Ravi Vakil 84)

  • 2.4.N. E XERCISE . Suppose ϕ : F → G is a morphism of sheaves of sets on a topological space X. Show that the following are equivalent. (Ravi Vakil 85)

  • ϕ is injective on the level of stalks (Ravi Vakil 85)
  • ϕ is injective on the level of open (Ravi Vakil 85)
  • use the “indicator sheaf” with one section over every open set contained in U, and no section over any other open set. (Ravi Vakil 85)
  • If these conditions hold, we say that F is a subsheaf of G (Ravi Vakil 85)
  • (a) (Ravi Vakil 85)
  • (b) (Ravi Vakil 85)
  • (c) (Ravi Vakil 85)
  • show that for any morphism of presheaves, if all maps of sections are injective, then all stalk maps (Ravi Vakil 85)
  • are injective. (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • show that the following are equivalent. (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • ϕ is an epimorphism (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • ϕ is surjective on the level of stalks (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • (a) (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • (b) (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • If these conditions hold, we say that G is a quotient sheaf of F . (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • monomorphisms and epimorphisms — subsheafiness and quotient sheafiness — can be checked at the level of stalks. (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • Both exercises generalize readily to sheaves with values in any reasonable category, (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • surjectivity on all open sets in the base of a topology implies that the corresponding map of sheaves is an epimorphism, (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • Let X = C with the classical topology, and define OX to be the sheaf of holomorphic functions, and OX∗ to be the sheaf of invertible (nowhere zero) holomorphic functions (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • ×2πi exp (2.4.10.1) 0 /Z / OX / O ∗ X /1 (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • where Z is the constant sheaf associated to Z. (Ravi Vakil 86)

  • 2.4.P. E NLIGHTENING E XERCISE . Show that exp : OX / O ∗ describes O ∗ as X X a quotient sheaf of OX . Find an open set on which this map is not surjective. (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • This is a great example to get a sense of what “surjectivity” means for sheaves: nowhere vanishing holomorphic functions have logarithms locally, but they need not globally. (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • we can understand sheaves using (Ravi Vakil 86)
  • stalks (using “compatible germs”) (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • We now introduce a second way of getting a hold of sheaves, by introducing the notion of a sheaf on a base. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • the central insight that this partial information is enough to understand germs, (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • Then a base of a topology is a subcollection of the open sets {Bj } ⊂ {Ui }, such that each Ui is a union of the Bj (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • to check continuity of some map π : X → Rn , you need only think about the pullback of balls on Rn — part of the traditional δ-ϵ definition of continuity. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • We can recover the entire sheaf from this information. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • which is a subset of the information contained in the sheaf — we are only paying attention to the information involving elements of the base, not all open sets. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • Then consider the information (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • Now suppose we have a sheaf F on a topological space X, and a base {Bi } of open sets on X. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • we can determine the stalks from this information, and we can determine when germs are compatible. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • 2.5.A. I MPORTANT E XERCISE . Make this precise. How can you recover a sheaf F from this partial information? (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • A sheaf of sets (or abelian groups, rings, . . . ) on a base {Bi } is the following. For each Bi in the base, we have a set F(Bi ). If Bi ⊂ Bj , we have maps resBj ,Bi : F(Bj ) → F(Bi ), with resBi ,Bi = id F(B i ) . (Things called “B” are always assumed to be in the base.) If Bi ⊂ Bj ⊂ Bk , then resBk ,Bi (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • = resBj ,Bi ◦ resBk ,Bj . So far we have defined a presheaf on a base {Bi }. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • the base identity axiom: If B = ∪Bi , then if f, g ∈ F(B) are such that resB,Bi f = resB,Bi g for all i, then f = g. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • base gluability axiom too: If B = ∪Bi , and we have fi ∈ F(B i ) such that fi agrees with fj on any basic open set contained in Bi ∩ Bj (i.e., resB i ,Bk fi = resBj ,Bk fj for all Bk ⊂ Bi ∩ Bj ) then there exists f ∈ F(B) such that resB,B i f = fi for all i. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • 2.5.1. Theorem. — Suppose {Bi } is a base on X, and F is a sheaf of sets on this base. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • Then there is a sheaf F extending F (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • This sheaf F is unique up to unique isomorphism. (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • Define the stalk of a presheaf F on a base at p ∈ X by F p = lim F(Bi ) −→ (Ravi Vakil 87)
  • where the colimit is over all Bi (in the base) containing p. (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • a family of germs in an open set U is compatible near p if there is a section s of F over some Bi containing p such that the germs over Bi are precisely the germs of s. (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • 2.5.B. E XERCISE . Verify that F(B) → F (B) is an isomorphism (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • F (U) := {(fp ∈ Fp )p∈U : for all p ∈ U, there exists B with p ∈ B ⊂ U, s ∈ F(B), with sq = fq for all q ∈ B} (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • where each B is in our base. (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • the restriction maps for F are the same as the restriction maps of F (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • F is indeed unique up to unique isomorphism (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • Theorem 2.5.1 shows that sheaves on X can be recovered from their “restriction to a base”. (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • that if F is a sheaf and F is the corresponding sheaf on the base B, then for any p ∈ X, Fp is naturally isomorphic to Fp . (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • 2.5.C. I MPORTANT E XERCISE : M ORPHISMS OF SHEAVES CORRESPOND TO MOR PHISMS OF SHEAVES ON A BASE (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • (a) Verify that a morphism of sheaves is determined by the induced morphism of sheaves on the base. (b) Show that a morphism of sheaves on the base gives a morphism of the induced sheaves. (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • 2.5.2. Remark. The above constructions and arguments describe an equivalence of categories (§1.2.21) between sheaves on X and sheaves on a given base of X (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • What are the functors in each direction? Why aren’t their compositions the identity? (Ravi Vakil 88)
  • (really, equivalence of categories) between OX -modules and “OX -modules on a base”. (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • what is an “OX -module on a base”? Given an OX -module on a base, why is the corresponding sheaf naturally an OX -module? (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • Suppose X = ∪Ui is an open cover of X, and we have sheaves Fi on Ui along with isomorphisms ϕij : Fi |Ui ∩Uj → Fj |Ui ∩Uj (with ϕ ii the identity) that agree on triple overlaps, i.e., ϕjk ◦ ϕij = ϕik on Ui ∩ Uj ∩ U (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • cocycle condition (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • 2.5.D. I MPORTANT E XERCISE . (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • Show that these sheaves can be glued together into a sheaf F on X (unique up to unique isomor∼ phism), such that Fi = ∼ F |U , and the isomorphisms over Ui ∩ Uj are the obvious = i ones. (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • we are not assuming this is a finite cover, so you cannot use induction. (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • 2.5.5. Remark for experts. Exercise 2.5.D almost says that the “set” of sheaves forms a sheaf itself, but not quite. Making this precise leads one to the notion of a stack. (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • This gives a useful sufficient criterion for “surjectivity”: a morphism of sheaves is an epimorphism (“surjective”) if it is surjective for sections on a base. (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • showing that the exponential map exp : OX → OX∗ is surjective, using the base of contractible open sets. (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • 2.5.E. U NIMPORTANT EXERCISE . Suppose a morphism of sheaves F → G on a base {Bi } is surjective for all Bi (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • Show that the corresponding morphism of sheaves (not on the base) is surjective (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • The converse is not true (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • kernels, cokernels, exactness, and so forth can be understood at the level of stalks (Ravi Vakil 89)
  • The category of sheaves of abelian groups on a topological space X is clearly an additive category (Ravi Vakil 90)
  • we must begin by showing that any morphism ϕ : F → G has a kernel and a cokernel (Ravi Vakil 90)
  • In order to show that it is an abelian category, (Ravi Vakil 90)
  • 2.6.A. E XERCISE . Show that the stalk of the kernel is the kernel of the stalks (Ravi Vakil 90)
  • 2.6.1. Proposition. — The composition G → H is the cokernel of ϕ in the category of sheaves. (Ravi Vakil 90)
  • 2.6.B. E XERCISE . Show that the stalk of the cokernel is naturally isomorphic to the cokernel of the stalk. (Ravi Vakil 90)
  • 2.6.2. Theorem. — Sheaves of abelian groups on a topological space X form an abelian category. (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • Show that the image sheaf im ϕ is the sheafification of the image presheaf. (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • exactness of a sequence of sheaves may be checked at the level of stalks (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • Show that taking the stalk of a sheaf of abelian groups is an exact functor. (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • 2.6.E. E XERCISE . Check that the exponential exact sequence (2.4.10.1) is exact. (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • and 0 → F → G → H is an exact sequence of sheaves of abelian groups. Show that 0 → F (U) → G (U) → H (U) is exact (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • 2.6.F. E XERCISE : L EFTEXACTNESS OF THE FUNCTOR OF “ SECTIONS OVER U”. (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • Show that the section functor need not be exact (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • show that 0 → π∗ F → π∗ G → π∗ H is exact. (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • π : X → Y is a continuous map, (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • Suppose 0 → F → G → H is an exact sequence of sheaves of abelian groups on X. If (Ravi Vakil 91)
  • 2.6.H. E XERCISE : L EFTEXACTNESS OF Hom (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • Show that Hom (F , ·) is a left-exact covariant functor AbX → AbX . Show that Hom (·, F ) is a left-exact contravariant functor AbX → AbX (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • 2.6.I. E XERCISE . Show that if (X, OX ) is a ringed space, then OX -modules form an abelian category (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • because a sequence of OX -modules is exact if and only if the underlying sequence of sheaves of abelian groups is exact. (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • Many facts about sheaves of abelian groups carry over to OX -modules without change (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • 2.6.J. I MPORTANT E XERCISE : T ENSOR PRODUCTS OF OX MODULES . (a) Suppose OX is a sheaf of rings on X. Define (categorically) what we should mean by tensor product of two OX -modules. (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • Show that the tensor product of stalks is the stalk of the tensor product. (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • colimits commute with tensor products”.) (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • 2.6.5. Conclusion. Just as presheaves are abelian categories because all abeliancategorical notions make sense open set by open set, sheaves are abelian categories because all abelian-categorical notions make sense stalk by stalk. (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • 2.7.1. Definition by adjoint: elegant but abstract. We define the inverse image π−1 as the left adjoint to π∗ . (Ravi Vakil 92)
  • Now define the inverse image of G by π−1 G := (π−1 pre −1 pre G ) sh (Ravi Vakil 93)
  • 2.7.B. I MPORTANT T RICKY E XERCISE . If π : X → Y is a continuous map, and F is a sheaf on X and G is a sheaf on Y, describe a bijection MorX (π−1 G , F ) ↔︎ MorY (G , π∗ F ). (Ravi Vakil 93)
  • stalk and skyscraper are an adjoint pair” (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • X is a point p ∈ Y, we see that π−1 G is the stalk Gp of G , and maps from the stalk Gp to a set S are the same as maps of sheaves on Y from G to the skyscraper sheaf with set S supported at p (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • 2.7.C. E XERCISE . Show that the stalks of π−1 G are the same as the stalks of G . (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • show that i−1 G is naturally isomorphic to G |U (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • Show that π−1 is an exact functor from sheaves of abelian groups on Y to sheaves of abelian groups on X (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • Define the support of a sheaf G of sets, denoted Supp G , as the locus where the stalks are not the oneelement set: Supp G := {p ∈ X : |Gp | ̸= 1}. (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • the support consists of points where the stalk is not the final object (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • Show that the natural map G → i∗ i−1 G is an isomorphism (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • Thus a sheaf supported on a closed subset can be considered a sheaf on that closed subset. (Ravi Vakil 94)
  • In addition to always being a left adjoint, π−1 can sometimes be a right adjoint. (Ravi Vakil 95)
  • Recall that a topological space with a sheaf of rings is called a ringed space (Ravi Vakil 99)
  • hus we will define a scheme to be the following data • • • The set: the points of the scheme The topology: the open sets of the scheme The structure sheaf: the sheaf of “algebraic functions” (a sheaf of rings) on the scheme. (Ravi Vakil 99)
  • For the set, in the key example of complex (affine) varieties (roughly, things cut out in Cn by polynomials), we will see that the points are the “traditional points” (n-tuples of complex numbers), plus some extra points that will be handy to have around (Ravi Vakil 99)
  • we will require that “the subset where an algebraic function vanishes must be closed”, and require nothing else. (Ravi Vakil 99)
  • (3x 2 +y2 )/(2x+4xy+1) (Ravi Vakil 99)
  • should be an algebraic function on the open set consisting of points where the denominator doesn’t vanish, (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • valuation at a point p ∈ X gives a surjective map from the stalk to R OX,p / / R, (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • so the kernel, the (germs of) functions vanishing at p, is a maximal ideal mX,p (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • In the algebraic setting, the basic patch is the notion of an affine scheme, (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • dditional requirement that the topological space be Hausdorff, to avoid pathologies. Schemes are often required to be “separated” to avoid essentially the same pathologies (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • unctions are determined by their values at points. This is an obvious statement, but won’t be true for schemes in general (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • Morphisms of manifolds. How can we describe differentiable maps of manifolds π : X → Y? (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • we have a map π−1 OY → OX . (The inverse image sheaf π−1 was defined in §2.7.) Inverse image is left-adjoint to pushforward, so we also get a map π♯ : OY → π∗ OX . (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • 3.1.A. I MPORTANT E XERCISE FOR THOSE WITH A LITTLE EXPERIENCE WITH MAN IFOLDS (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • Show that π is differentiable if differentiable functions pull back to differentiable functions, i.e., if pullback by π gives a map OY → π∗ OX (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • Suppose that π : X → Y is a continuous map of differentiable manifolds (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • 3.1.B. E XERCISE . Show that a morphism of differentiable manifolds π : X → Y with π(p) = q induces a morphism of stalks π♯ : OY,q → OX,p . Show that π ♯ (m Y,q ) ⊂ mX,p (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • In other words, if you pull back a function that vanishes at (Ravi Vakil 100)
  • q, you get a function that vanishes at p — not a huge surprise (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • maps of differentiable manifolds are maps of locally ringed spaces (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • Notice that π induces a map on tangent spaces (see Aside 2.1.2) (m /m2X,p ) ∨ → (mY,q /m2Y,q )∨ . (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • Again, it is interesting that the cotangent map mY,q /m2Y,q → mX,p /m2X,p is algebraically more natural than the tangent map (there are no “duals”). (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • For example: how can one check if π is a submersion of manifolds? How can one check if f is an immersion? (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • the algebro-geometric version of these notions are smooth morphism and unramified morphism; (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • Manifolds are covered by disks that are all isomorphic. This isn’t true for schemes (even for “smooth complex varieties”). There are examples of two “smooth complex curves” (the algebraic version of Riemann surfaces) X and Y so that no nonempty open subset of X is isomorphic to a nonempty open subset of Y (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • And there is a Riemann surface X such that no two open subsets of X are isomorphic (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • this is because in the Zariski topology on schemes, all nonempty open sets are “huge” and have more “structure”. (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • we will define a sheaf of rings on it (the structure sheaf) (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • Such an object is called an affine scheme (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • Later Spec A will denote the set along with the topology, and a sheaf of functions. (Ravi Vakil 101)
  • The set Spec A is the set of prime ideals of A (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • The prime ideal p of A when considered as an element of Spec A will be denoted [p], (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • Elements a ∈ A will be called functions on Spec A, and their value at the point [p] will be a (mod p). (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • a function can take values in different rings at different points — the function 5 on Spec Z takes the value 1 (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • (mod 2) at [(2)] and 2 (mod 3) at [(3)]. (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • “An element a of the ring lying in a prime ideal p” translates to “a function a that is 0 at the point [p]” or “a function a vanishing at the point [p]” (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • Notice that if you add or multiply two functions, you add or multiply their values at all points; this is a translation of the fact that A → A/p is a ring morphism. These translations are important (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • If A is generated over a base field (or base ring) by elements x1 , . . . , xr , the elements x1 , . . . , xr are often called coordinates, (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • we will interpret functions on Spec A as global sections of the “structure sheaf”, i.e., as a function on a ringed space (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • what we will call “functions”, others may call “regular functions”. And we will later define “rational functions” (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • which are not precisely functions in this sense; they are a particular type of “partially-defined function”. (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • The notion of “value of a function” will be later interpreted as a value of a function on a particular locally ringed space (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • A1C := Spec C[x] (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • Let’s find the prime ideals of C[x]. As C[x] is an integral domain, 0 is prime. Also, (x − a) is prime, for any a ∈ C: it is even a maximal ideal, as the quotient by this ideal is a field: f7→f(a) 0 / (x − a) / C[x] /C /0 (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • We now show that there are no other prime ideals. We use the fact that C[x] has a division algorithm, and is a unique factorization domain. (Ravi Vakil 102)
  • There is one “traditional” point for each complex number, plus one extra (“bonus”) point [(0)]. (Ravi Vakil 103)
  • This new point [(0)] is called the “generic point” of the line. (Ravi Vakil 103)
  • The functions on A1C are the polynomials (Ravi Vakil 103)
  • So f(x) = x2 − 3x + 1 is a function. What is its value at [(x − 1)], which we think of as the point 1 ∈ C? Answer: f(1)! Or equivalently, we can evaluate f(x) modulo x − 1 — this is the same thing by the division algorithm. (Ravi Vakil 103)
  • We want to say that g(x) has a triple zero at 3, and a single pole at 2 (Ravi Vakil 103)
  • g(x) = (x − 3)3 /(x − 2) is a “rational function”. It is defined everywhere but x = 2 (Ravi Vakil 103)
  • A1k := Spec k[x] (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • where k is an algebraically closed field. (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • Spec Z. An amazing fact is that from our perspective, this will look a lot like the affine line Ak1 (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • The integers, like k[x], form a unique factorization domain, with a division algorithm. The prime ideals are: (0), and (p) where p is prime. (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • Our picture of Spec Z is shown in Figure 3.2. (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • 100 is a function on Spec Z. Its value at (3) is “1 (mod 3)”. Its value at (2) is “0 (mod 2)”, and in fact it has a double zero. 27/4 is a “rational function” on Spec Z, defined away from (2). We want to say that it has a double pole at (2), and a triple zero at (3). Its value at (5) is 27 × 4−1 ≡ 2 × (−1) ≡ 3 (mod 5) (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • The set Spec k where k is any field is boring: one point. Spec 0, where 0 is the zero-ring, is the empty set, as 0 has no prime ideals. (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • The ring k[ϵ]/(ϵ2 ) is called the ring of dual numbers (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • 3.2.A. A SMALL EXERCISE ABOUT SMALL SCHEMES . (a) Describe the set Spec k[ϵ]/(ϵ2 ) (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • It is a nonzero function whose value at all points is zero, thus giving our first example of functions not being determined by their values at points (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • Describe the set Spec k[x](x) (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • think of it as a shred of a particularly nice “smooth curve”. (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • the prime ideals are (0), (x − a) where a ∈ R, and (x2 + ax + b) where x2 + ax + b is an irreducible quadratic. The latter two are maximal ideals, i.e., their quotients ∼ are fields. For example: R[x]/(x − 3) = ∼ R, R[x]/(x2 + 1) = = ∼ C. (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • A1R = Spec R[x]. (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • Using the fact that R[x] is a Euclidean domain domain (Ravi Vakil 104)
  • 3.2.B. U NIMPORTANT E XERCISE . Show that for the last type of prime, of the form (x 2 + ax + b), the quotient is always isomorphic to C. (Ravi Vakil 105)
  • So we have the points that we would normally expect to see on the real line, corresponding to real numbers; the generic point 0; and new points which we may interpret as conjugate pairs of complex numbers (the roots of the quadratic). (Ravi Vakil 105)
  • You can picture A1R as the complex plane, folded along the real axis. But the key point is that Galois-conjugate points (such as i and −i) are considered glued. (Ravi Vakil 105)
  • 3.2.5. Hilbert’s Nullstellensatz. — If k is any field, every maximal ideal of k[x1 , . . . , xn ] has residue field a finite extension of k. Translation: any field extension of k that is finitely generated as a ring is necessarily also finitely generated as a module (i.e., is a finite extension of fields). (Ravi Vakil 107)
  • 3.2.4. Hilbert’s Weak Nullstellensatz. — If k is an algebraically closed field, then the maximal ideals of k[x1 , . . . , xn ] are precisely those ideals of the form (x1 − a1 , . . . , xn − a n ), where ai ∈ k. (Ravi Vakil 107)
  • 3.2.F. E XERCISE . satz 3.2.4. (Ravi Vakil 107)
  • Show that the Nullstellensatz 3.2.5 implies the Weak Nullstellen- (Ravi Vakil 107)

08/04/2020: Topology (James R. Munkres)

/home/zack/Dropbox/Library/James R. Munkres/Topology (416)/Topology - James R. Munkres.pdf

Last Annotation: 08/04/2020

Notes

  • Proof of tube lemma (James R. Munkres 182)
  • Heine Borel (James R. Munkres 188)

Highlights

  • Theorem 10.1. Every nonempty finite ordered set has the order type of a section {1,...,n}of Z,, soitis well-ordered. (James R. Munkres 79)
  • Theorem (Well-ordering theorem). A that is a well-ordering. (James R. Munkres 80)
  • Corollary. There exists an uncountable well-ordered set. (James R. Munkres 81)
  • Definition. Let X be a well-ordered set Given a € X, let S, denote the set Se ={x|x € Xandx < a}. [t is called the section of X by a. (James R. Munkres 81)
  • Lemma 10.2. There exists a well-ordered set A having a largest element 2, such that the section Sq of A by 2 is uncountable but every other section of A is countable. (James R. Munkres 81)
  • Theorem 10.3. If A is a countable subset of Sq, then A has an upper bound in Sq (James R. Munkres 81)
  • 1. Show that every well-ordered set has the least upper bound property. (James R. Munkres 81)
  • Note that Sq 1s an uncountable well-ordered set every section of which is countable Its order type is in fact uniquely determined by this condition. We shall call it a minimal uncountable well-ordered set. (James R. Munkres 81)
  • Zorn’s Lemma. Let A be a set that is strctly partially ordered. If every simply ordered subset of A has an upper bound in A, then A has a maximal element. (James R. Munkres 85)
  • Definition. A topology on a set X is a collection T of subsets of X having the following properties: (1) @and X arein 7. (2) The union of the elements of any subcollection of 7 1s in 7. (3) The intersection of the elements of any finite subcollection of 7 is in 7. (James R. Munkres 91)
  • A set X for which a topology 7 has been specified is called a topological space. (James R. Munkres 91)
  • Definition. If X is a set, a basis for a topology on X is a collection B of subsets of X (called basis elements) such that (1) Foreach x € X, there is at least one basis element B containing x. (2) If x belongs to the intersection of two basis elements B; and B3, then there is a basis element B3 containing x such that B3 C B N B,. (James R. Munkres 93)
  • A subset U of X is said to be open in X (that is, to be an element of 77) if for each x € U, there 1s a basis element B € B such that x € B and B C U. (James R. Munkres 93)
  • A subset A of a topological space X is said to be closed if the set X — A is open. (James R. Munkres 108)
  • product of open sets of R andis, therefore, open in R2 (James R. Munkres 108)
  • Y= [0’ I]U (2’ 3)’ (James R. Munkres 108)
  • These examples suggest that an answer to the mathematician’s riddle: “How is a set different from a door?” should be: “A door must be either open or closed, and cannot be both, while a set can be open, or closed, or both, or neither!” (James R. Munkres 108)
  • “U is an open set containing x” to the phrase “U is a neighborhood of x.” (James R. Munkres 111)
  • If A is a subset of the topological space X and if x is a point of X, we say thatx is a limit point (or “cluster point,” or “point of accumulation™) of A if every neighborhood of x intersects A in some point other than x itself. (James R. Munkres 112)
  • Said differently, x is a limit point of A if it belongs to the closure of A — {x} (James R. Munkres 112)
  • Definition. A topological space X is called a Hausdorffspaceif for each pair x|, x; of distinct points of X, there exist neighborhoods Uy, and Uof x; and x3, respectively, that are disjoint. (James R. Munkres 113)
  • . Show that X is Hausdorff if and only if the diagonal A = (x x x | x € X} is closed in X x X. (James R. Munkres 116)
  • Ax B=A x B. (James R. Munkres 116)
  • Theorem 18.1. Let X and Y be topological spaces; let f : X — Y. Then the following are equivalent: (1) f is continuous. (2) For every subset A of X, one has f(/i) m (3) Forevery closed set B of Y, the set f ~1(B) is closed in X (4) For each x € X and each neighborhood V of f(x), there is a neighborhood U of x such that f(U) C V. (James R. Munkres 119)
  • If the condition in (4) holds for the point x of X, we say that f is continuous at the point x . (James R. Munkres 119)
  • Definition. Let X and Y be topological spaces; let p : X — Y be a surjective map. The map p is said to be a quotient map provided a subset U of Y is open in Y if and only if p~!(U) is openin X. (James R. Munkres 152)
  • This condition is stronger than continuity; some mathematicians call it *“strong continuity.” An equivalent condition is to require that a subset A of Y be closed in Y if and only if p~’(A) is closed in X. (James R. Munkres 152)
  • We say that a subset C of X is saturated (with respect to the surjective map p : X — Y)if C contains every set p~!({y}) that it intersects. Thus C is saturated if it equals the complete inverse image of a subset of Y. (James R. Munkres 152)
  • To say that p is a quotient map is equivalent to saying that p 1s continuous and p maps saturated open sets of X to open sets of Y (or saturated closed sets of X to closed sets of Y). (James R. Munkres 152)
  • Definition. If X is a space and A is aset and if p : X — A is a surjective map, then there exists exactly one topology 7 on A relative to which p i1s a quotient map; 1t is called the quotient topology induced by p. (James R. Munkres 153)
  • The topology 7 is of course defined by letting it consist of those subsets U of A such that p~!(U) is open in X. (James R. Munkres 153)
  • Definition. Let X be a topological space, and let X* be a partition of X into disjoint subsets whose union is X. Let p : X — X* be the surjective map that carries each point of X to the element of X* containing it. In the quotient topology induced by p, the space X™* is called a quotient space of X. (James R. Munkres 154)
  • One can show that X* is homeomorphic with the subspace of R called the unit 2-sphere, (James R. Munkres 154)
  • Theorem 22.1. Letp: X — Y be a quotient map; let A be a subspace of X that is saturated with respect to p; letq : A — p(A) be the map obtained by restricting p. (1) If A is either open or closed in X, then q is a quotient map. *(2) If p is either an open map or a closed map, then q is a quotient map. (James R. Munkres 155)
  • it is easy to check that the composite of two quotient mapsis a quotient map; (James R. Munkres 156)
  • p g™ (W) = (g0 p) (V). (James R. Munkres 156)
  • On the other hand, products of maps do not behave well; the cartesian product of two quotient maps need not be a quotient map. (James R. Munkres 156)
  • One needs further conditions on either the maps or the spaces in order for this statement to be true. One such, a condition on the spaces,is called local compactness;, w (James R. Munkres 156)
  • Another, a condition on the maps, is the condition that both the maps p and g be open maps. In that case, it is easy to see that p x g is also an open map, so 1t is a quotient map. (James R. Munkres 156)
  • Finally, the Hausdorff condition does not behave well; even if X i1s Hausdorff, there is no reason that the quotient space X * needs to be Hausdorff. (James R. Munkres 156)
  • . There is a simple condition for X* to satisfy the T} axiom; one simply requires that each element ofthe partition X* be a closed subset of X. (James R. Munkres 156)
  • Theorem 22.2. Let p : X — Y be a quotient map. Let Z be a space and let g : X — Z be a map that is constant on each set p~ ’y}, fory € Y. Then g induces amap f : Y — Z such that f o p = g. The induced map f is continuous if and only if g is continuous; f is a quotient map if and only if g is a quotient map. (James R. Munkres 157)
  • Lemma 23.1. IfY is a subspace of X, a separation of Y is a pair of disjoint nonempty sets A and B whose union is Y, neither of which contains a limit point of the other. The space Y is connected if there exists no separation of Y. (James R. Munkres 163)
  • A space X is connected if and only if the only subsets of X that are both open and closed in X are the empty set and X itself. (James R. Munkres 163)
  • Definition. Let X be atopological space. A separation of X is a pair U, V ofdisjoint nonempty open subsets of X whose union is X. The space X is said to be connected if there does not exist a separation of X. (James R. Munkres 163)
  • For if A is a nonempty proper subset of X that is both open and closed in X, then the sets U = A and V = X — A constitute a separation of X, for they are open, disjoint, and nonempty, and their union is X. Conversely, if U and V form a separation of X, then U is nonempty and different from X, and it is both open and closed in X. (James R. Munkres 163)
  • Suppose first that A and B form a separation of Y. Then A is both open and closed in Y. The closure of A in Y is the set AN Y (where A as usual denotes the closure of A in X). Since A is closed in Y, A = ANY; or to say the same thing, AN B = @. Since A is the union of A and its limit points, B contains no limit points of A. A similar argument shows that A contains no limit points of B. (James R. Munkres 163)
  • Conversely, suppose that A and B are disjoint nonempty sets whose union is Y, neither of which contains a limit point of the other. Then ANB =@ and AN B = &; (James R. Munkres 163)
  • therefore, we conclude that ANY = A and BNY = B. Thus both A and B are closed inY,andsince A=Y — Band B =Y — A, they are openin Y as well. (James R. Munkres 164)
  • The rationals QQ are not connected. (James R. Munkres 164)
  • Indeed, the only connected subspaces of Q are the one-point sets: (James R. Munkres 164)
  • Lemma 23.2. If the sets C and D form a separation of X, and if Y is a connected subspace of X, then Y lies entirely within either C or D. (James R. Munkres 164)
  • Theorem 23.3. The union of a collection of connected subspaces of X that have a point in common Is connected. (James R. Munkres 165)
  • Proof. Let{A4} be acollection of connected subspaces of a space X; let p be a point of () Aa. We prove that the space Y = ) A4 is connected. Suppose that Y = CU D is a separation of Y. The point p is in one of the sets C or D; suppose p € C. Since A, is connected, it must lie entirely in either C or D, and it cannot lie in D because it contains the point p of C. Hence A, C C for every a, so that | JA, C C, contradicting the fact that D is nonempty. (James R. Munkres 165)
  • Theorem 23.4. connected. (James R. Munkres 165)
  • Let A be a connected subspace of X. If A C B C A, then B is also (James R. Munkres 165)
  • Theorem 23.6. A finite cartesian product of connected spaces is connected. (James R. Munkres 165)
  • Proof. We prove the theorem first for the product of two connected spaces X and Y. This proofis easy to visualize. Choose a “base point” a x b in the product X x Y. Note that the “‘honzontal slice” X x b is connected, being homeomorphic with X, and each “vertical slice” x x Y is connected, being homeomorphic with Y. As a result, each *“T-shaped” space T,=(Xxb)U(x xY) is connected, being the union of two connected spaces that have the point x x b in common. See Figure 23.2. Now form the union J, .y T of all these T-shaped spaces. (James R. Munkres 165)
  • This union is connected because it is the union of a collection of connected spaces that have the point a x b in common. Since this union equals X x Y, the space X x Y is connected. (James R. Munkres 166)
  • Definition. Given X, define an equivalence relation on X by setting x ~ y if there is a connected subspace of X containing both x and y. The equivalence classes are called the components (or the “connected components”) of X. (James R. Munkres 174)
  • Theorem 25.1. The components of X are connected disjoint subspaces ot X whose union is X, such that each nonempty connected subspace of X intersects only one of them. (James R. Munkres 174)
  • Definition. We define another equivalence relation on the space X by defining x ~ y if there is a path in X from x to y. The equivalence classes are called the path components of X. (James R. Munkres 175)
  • Definition. A space X is said to be locally connected at x if for every neighborhood U ofx, there is a connected neighborhood V of x contained in U. If X is locally connected at each of its points, it is said simply to be locally connected. Similarly, a space X is said to be locally path connected at x if for every neighborhood U of x, there is a path-connected neighborhood V of x contained in U. If X is locally path connected at each ofits points,then it is said to be locally path connected. (James R. Munkres 176)
  • Theorem 25.3. A space X is locally connected if and only if for every open set U of X, each component of U i1s openin X. (James R. Munkres 176)
  • Theorem 25.4. A space X is locally path connected if and only if for every open set U of X, each path component of U is openin X. (James R. Munkres 176)
  • Theorem 25.3. A space X is locally connected if and only if for every open set U of X, each component of U i1s openin X. (James R. Munkres 176)
  • ExXAMPLE 3. Each interval and each ray (James R. Munkres 176)

  • Lemma 26.1. LetY be a subspace of X. Then Y is compact if and only if every covering of Y by sets open in X contains a finite subcollection covering Y. (James R. Munkres 179)
  • EXAMPLE 2. The following subspace of R is compact: X=(0ju(l/n|neZy). Given an open covering A of X, there is an element U of A containing 0. The set U contains all but finitely many of the points 1/n; choose, for each point of X not in U/, an element of A containing it. The collection consisting of these elements of A, along with the element U, is a finite subcollection of A that covers X. (James R. Munkres 179)
  • Definition. A space X is said to be compact if every open covering + of X contains a finite subcollection that also covers X. (James R. Munkres 179)
  • Definition. A collection A of subsets of a space X is said to cover X, or to be a covering of X, if the union of the elements of A is equal to X. It is called an open covering of X if its elements are open subsets of X. (James R. Munkres 179)
  • EXAMPLE 3. Any space X containing only finitely many points is necessarily compact, because in this case every open covering of X is finite. (James R. Munkres 179)
  • If Y is a subspace of X, a collection A of subsets of X is said to cover Y if the union ofits elements contains Y . (James R. Munkres 179)
  • Theorem 26.2. Every closed subspace of a compact space is compact. (James R. Munkres 180)
  • Theorem 26.3. Every compact subspace of a Hausdorff space is closed. (James R. Munkres 180)
  • We show there is a neighborhood of xq that is disjoint from Y (James R. Munkres 180)
  • Theorem 26.5. The image of a compact space under a continuous map is compact. (James R. Munkres 181)

  • Lemma 26.8 (The tube lemma). Consider the product space X x Y, where Y is compact. If N is an open set of X x Y containing the slice xo x Y of X x Y, then N contains some tube W x Y about xo x Y, where W is a neighborhood of xq in X . (James R. Munkres 183)
  • The tube lemma is certainly not true if Y is not compact (James R. Munkres 183)
  • is nonempty. (James R. Munkres 185)

  • Theorem 27.3. A subspace A of R" is compact if and only if it is closed and is bounded in the euclidean metric d or the square metric p. (James R. Munkres 188)
  • Theorem 27.4 (Extreme value theorem). Let f . X — Y be continuous, where Y is an ordered set in the order topology. If X 1s compact, then there exist points ¢ and d in X such that f(c) < f(x) < f(d) foreveryx € X. (James R. Munkres 189)
  • The extreme value theorem of calculus is the special case of this theorem that occurs when we take X to be a closed interval in R and Y to be R. (James R. Munkres 189)
  • Definition. A space X is said to be locally compact at x if there is some compact subspace C of X that contains a neighborhood of x. If X is locally compact at each of its points, X is said simply to be locally compact. (James R. Munkres 197)
  • Definition. If a space X has a countable basis for its topology, then X is said to satisfy the second countability axiom, or to be second-countable. (James R. Munkres 205)
  • EXAMPLE 2 In the uniform topology, Rs (James R. Munkres 205)
  • Definition. A subset A of a space X is said to be dense in X if A = X. (James R. Munkres 206)
  • Theorem 30.3. Suppose that X has a countable basis. Then: (a) Every open covering of X contains a countable subcollection covering X . (b) There exists a countable subset of X that is dense in X. (James R. Munkres 206)
  • Proof (James R. Munkres 206)
  • (b) From each nonempty basis element B,, choose a point x,. Let D be the set consisting of the points x,. Then D is dense in X: Given any point x of X, every basis elementcontaining x intersects D, so x belongs to D. (James R. Munkres 206)
  • A space for which every open covenng contains a countable subcovering is called a Lindelof space A space having a countable dense subset 1s often said to be separable (James R. Munkres 207)
  • each of these properties is equivalent to the second countability axiom when the space is metnzable (James R. Munkres 207)
  • Definition. A metnc space (X, d) is said to be totally bounded if for every € > 0, there is a finite covering of X by e-balls. (James R. Munkres 290)
  • Theorem 45.1. totally bounded. A metric space (X, d) is compact if and only if it is complete and (James R. Munkres 291)
  • to find the compact subspaces of the space C(X, R“), in the uniform topology. We know that a subspace of R” is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. One might hope that an analogous result holds for C (X, R“). But it does not, even if X is compact. One needs to assume that the subspace of C(X, R”) satisfies an additional condition, called equicontinuity. (James R. Munkres 291)

  • Theorem 55.6 (Brouwer fixed-point theorem for the disc). If f : B2 — B is continuous, then there exists a point x € B? such that f(x) = x. (James R. Munkres 366)

01/16/2020: Vakil Foundations of Algebraic Geometry (Vakil)

/home/zack/Dropbox/Library/Vakil/Vakil Foundations of Algebraic Geometry (681)/Vakil Foundations of Algebraic Geometry - Vakil.pdf

Last Annotation: 01/16/2020

Highlights

  • Germs are objects of the form {(f, open U) : p ∈ U, f ∈ O(U)} modulo the relation that (f, U) ∼ (g, V) if there is some open set W ⊂ U, V containing p where f|W = g|W (i.e., resU,W f = resV,W g). (Vakil 70)
  • Germs are objects of the form {(f, open U) : p ∈ U, f ∈ O(U)} modulo the relation that (f, U) ∼ (g, V) if there is some open set W ⊂ U, V containing p where f|W = g|W (i.e., resU,W f = resV,W g) (Vakil 70)

06/19/2019: Visual Geometry and Topology (Fomenko)

/home/zack/Dropbox/Library/Fomenko/Visual Geometry and Topology (720)/Visual Geometry and Topology - Fomenko.pdf

Last Annotation: 06/19/2019

Highlights

  • Theorem. Integer-valued homology groups of a sphere with 9 handles, where 9 is a non-negative integer, have the form: Ho = Z, HI = Z2g ,H2 = Z. (Fomenko 58)
  • Theorem. Integer-valued homology groups of a projective plane have the form Ho = Z, HI = Z2, H2 = O. (Fomenko 59)
  • Theorem. Integer-valued homology groups of the Klein bottle have the form Ho = Z, HI = Z E9 Z2, H2 = O. (Fomenko 59)
  • Theorem. Integer-valued homology groups of a non-orientable twodimensional closed surface have the form: Ho = Z, HI = Zk-I Ell Z2, H2=0. (Fomenko 60)
  • Next, we refer to the well-known algebraic theorem stating that any integer-valued matrix can, using the above-mentioned elementary transformations, be reduced to a canonical form. This canonical form is as follows: on the principal diagonal of the matrix (corning from the left top comer of the matrix) there stand nonzero invariant factors whose number is equal to the matrix rank. All the other matrix elements are equal to zero. (Fomenko 67)
  • Recall that the diagonal elements (invariant factors) obtained are so ordered that each of them is a divisor of a subsequent one. Invariant factors are uniquely determined by the matrix and can be calculated in (Fomenko 67)
  • terms of its minors. (Fomenko 68)
  • Theorem. Let Ilk be the number of k-dimensional simplexes of a simplicial complex X (which corresponds to a certain triangulation of the polyhedron X) and let Ik be the rank of the incidence matrix Ek. Then the k-dimensional Betti number (3k, i.e. the rank of the integer-valued homology group Hk(X), is equal to Ilk Ik Ik-I. Given this, we assume that I-I = In = O. Next, k-dimensional torsion coefficients of the group Hk(X) are those invariant factors of the incidence matrix Ek which are not equal to unity. For k = n these torsion coefficients are absent, i.e. the group Hn(X), where n = dim X, is always free (does not have finite-order elements). (Fomenko 69)
